editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Composed for the scholars of the free-school of Hadleigh in Suffolk.
And acted by them on Shrove-tuesday, being the sixth of February, 1626.

div.head: To my singular honest stationer, Mr. Robert Mylbourne, at his shop in decimo sexto, by the South door of Paul's.
div.p:
As you are a true bookseller, you must approve yourself a ●ue book-restorer: and therefore by book or by crook, see that you send back my book. And yet not my book. For it was but a borrowed book, for which my promise and credit lie in mortgage to the author, the schoolmaster of ha●y, who with some difficulty lent it me, having no other copy of this English lesson w●. he prepared for ●a by-exercise for his scholars at the last Carnival. He told me that he huddled it up in haste, and that it being only an essay of his own faculty, and of the activity of his tenderlings, he was loath it should come under
any other eye, then of those parents and domestic friends who favourably beheld it, when it was represented by the children. And therefore, I must be, and am tender of suffering it to wander I know not whither, by the out let of your friend's hand: whom as I know not, so I cannot challenge of any trust; but require restitution of you, as the author doth of me. So, expecting without delay, the return of this bird into the cage, I end with a threat, that if you fail, you must look to have this comedy turned into a tragedy, and, for detaining this book, to have your name set on the back side of my book. Whereto I add yet a deeper curse, that next time you meet with good fellows in Epping forest, you may not be so happy, as to feed them with nuts in stead of money.

closer.signed: Yours as you shall deserve the endorsement of this my letter. E. W.

div.head: The aforesaid stationer's answer.

opener.salute: Loving, challenging, threatening friend, E. W.

div.p:
I pray you extend your love so far to your friend, and your friend's friend, as to think that neither the first will defraud you of your borrowed book, nor the second expose the author to any inconvenience. The truth is my friend, upon the sight of this moral, scholastical, theatrical treatise, protested that the author should receive much right in being thus wronged; and upon sufficient bond undertook to save me harmless if I made it more public than ever was intended. And withal he armed me with a legal defence, that, if I restored ten sold for the principal, the author (Notwithstanding his modesty) could frame no just quarrel against me or you at the bar of justice
or reputation. Accordingly he encouraged me (If master schoolmaster of Hadley should school● you for promise-breach) to stop his mouth with a dozen of chicken hatched under his own hen.
I pray you therefore in stead of his own single written Co●, copy him with this packet of his own mettle stamped and multiplied by the printers alchemy.

The w●st I hear, is, that he will complain to Apollo of me that I have proclaimed abroad his private shroving. For which I have a defence from the authors own pen, that Apollo's solemn visitation begins with proclamation. Act. 1. S●n. 〈◊〉 and, I trow proclamations are intended to fi● abroad in print. So in hope that I shall receive, if not thanks, yet pardon from him. I rather take, then beg, leave to remain still

closer.signed: Yours no less by this, R. m.
closer.dateline: London, april, 25. 1627. From the smell volume of my shop, where the South wi● blows into pa●ls.

div.head: Apollo shroving.
Composed for the scholars of the free-school of Hadleigh in Suffolk. And acted by them on Shrove-tuesday, being the 6. of February, 1626.

list.head: Dramatis personae.
list.label: Musaeus, Apollo's priest and judge.
Clio a muse, his assistant.
Euterpe a muse, another assistant.
Lawriger his verger.
Drudo his book-bearer.
preco the crier.
Thuriger the sexton of Apollo's temple.
Scopas the sexton's boy.
Philoponus a diligent student.
Amphibius a perplexed scholar.
Novice a young fresh scholar.
Rowland Retro an hasty non-proficient.
Ger● an old man, his mournful father.
Ludio a truantly schoolboy.
Siren a sea nymph, messenger from Queen Hedone.
captain compliment a teacher of gestures and fashions.
Jack implement his page.
miss indulgence Gingle, a coc●●g mother.
John Gingler son a disciple of captain: compliments.
Jug rubbish maidservant to mistress Gingle.
Slim slug, a lazy drone.
epilogue.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.p: Si quisquam est, qui placere se stu●at bonis quam plurimis, et mini●e multos laedere, in his pocta hic nomen profitetur suum.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: What? shall we have Latin again? Master 〈◊〉 youngster. I pray you go to the university, and set up your stage there.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: What, mistress Lala spinster? content yourself, I now repeat that which is past, I do not represent that which is present.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I pray you then tell us so much in honest English.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: I will, for your sake.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.l: For mine? nay, for every she,
Whom here you see:
And for our honest neighbours, many a good man that never
Was infected with this raving Latin ever.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Keep silence, thou particoloured chattering mappy.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: ●en speak sense, thou jabber all ▪ black jackdaw, with a green coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Good men, good wives, good ●nds, good maids, good boys.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I many, this 〈◊〉 for my stomach, ●me in the number of the fourth rank.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Who meet, to see, and hear our childish toys.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Well said, such easy drops sink well into our brains.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Of late ye know, if ye have not mistook us.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I do not mistake you now, you take us very well with your plain dealing English poetry.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: We acted comic Terence his eunuchus.

div.stage: He displays the outer end of the banner wherein is the name of eunuchus.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Eunuchus! Out upon him, and thee too, and all of his kin. I have heard my brother say, that this same Eunuchus is a man and no man,
The very scorn and hate of women.
I'll be sure, I'll hang, draw and quarter him; and for my part, sir prologue,She tears the paper.
I had rather ye should ●at us,
Then thus defeat us,
Then eunuch u●

sp.speaker: Prol
sp.p: For my part dame Lall, I do but act my part, you must not interrupt me.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I will n●t corrupt 〈◊〉 you, unless you name that hateful bilding jade. O what a queem he hath cast over my stomach with that filthy word.

sp.speaker: Pr●.
sp.l: But now w● condescend with mild audacity,
In vulgar language unto low capacity.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: See you ●old on your vulgar tongue, and bring not hither your latin vulgars, and lessons which you have chanced in the school.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.l: We come not with old worn common Thais,
By trade the sister of Corinthian Lais.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.l: Lais? Thais? Walk where your way is,
And tell us what this play is.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Nor Parmen●, nor scolding Pythias.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Thou pithless ass, dost thou tell us of scolding?

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.l: This wasp had almost put me out. Out with her.
But in a nearer circle now we walk,
Where with ourselves, and of ourselves we talk.
Our school imagine here new built and dight,
This scene our forms, our day this candle light.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Sir prologue, I fear thou talkest English extrumpery besides thy part, only to beguile me, I doubt there is Latin in his budget.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: I avow to thee, jealous Lala, that this same scholar's feast is dressed in English.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I dare not trust you, for you say you are here in the school. And you scholars must not speak English in the school.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: We are not now at our task, but we have leave to play, and we play at our best game.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: What? Blow point? or span-counter? or trap out may hap?
Take heed you grow not out.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: No tomboy, no. Nor scourge-top, nor truss, nor leap frog, nor nine holes, nor mumble the peg: but a more noble recreation, where we have more lookers on, than gamesters.

div.stage: He displays the Rowle upon his staff.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: What play call you it?

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Take out thy fescue, and spell here, in this one-leafed book. Tell the stitches in this samples of black and white.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: A. P. ap.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: A. P. ap? Thou fumbling ape. A. per se, a. P. o. L. pol.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: A. per se, a. P. o. L. pol, L. o. lo. Apollo. On my maidenhead this is Latin. We shall be choked with a doggerel Latin play for all this.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: I tell thee, this is Greek, Latin, and English too.

sp.speaker: L●la.
sp.p: This Apollo is he an English man? I'll deal with none but my own countrymen. I wont have to do, so I wont, with these outlandish people that speak gibberish.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: It is a proper name, it signifies the lord and master of the Muses. His throne and court here represented is the shop and staple of learning.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: A proper name? As you are a proper man, let none but English wares be sold in this shop, or else you have no customer of me.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Nay, read on what follows.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: S. H. R. O. shro. I'll none of this. What, do you call us shroves?

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Thou art not worthy to go a shroving, that canst not spell it.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: V i. N. G. ving, shroving I'm glad of that. Now I like this Apollo well: he'll go a gossipping with us. Does Apollo come a shroving to us, or shall we go a shroving to him?

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.l: All which we on this stage shall act or say,
Doth 〈◊〉 Apollo's shroving day.
Whilst thus we greet you by our words and pens,
Our sorouing bodeth death to none, but hens.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Pens? hens? Methinks the feathers of hens should not make good pens. I do not like the death of hens. As I'm a true housewife, I wondered what made our hen roost so empty, and see the scholars have gotten them.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: I prithee, hold thy peace, thou goest beyond thine office, thou'lt have the first word and the last too, thou show'st thyself to be a true Lala.
But whilst I chat with her, the time grows late, I'll six this banner at Apollo's gate. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: As I'm a true woman, I'll trust you slippery scholars no further than I see you. I wont away, till I taste of the first dish of Apollo's shroving seast, and know whether it was an English cook that dressed it.
I see a black coat come in, I'll know whether he be a true Britain.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ecce vigil nitido patefeci ab ortu
Purpureas aurora fores, et plena rosarum
Atria. Dissugiunt stellae, quarum agmina cogit
Lucifer, et coeli station novissimus exit.
Jungere equos Titan velocibus imperat beris.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I can hold no longer. False play. I bar your dice. Body o'me, I thought how we should be served.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What bold nymph is this, that durst intrude amongst the Muses?

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: O'my life, this is no English. My mother never spoke it. I proclaim to all of my sex, they have leave to depart. I'd rather spin at home, then hear these barbarians spout Latin, unless we had some kind scholar to tell us what they say. What a foppery is this, that we must laugh for company, and then ask what we laugh at.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ignorant suspicious soul, be content, I will be thine interpreter.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: If you do not interpret to me, I'll make you plum the play, you shan't be able to go on your part.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then so.
Now begins the fair dew dabbling blushing morn
To open to the earth heavens Eastern gate,
Displaying by degrees the new born light.
The stars have traced their dance, and unto night
Now bid good night.
The young day's sentinel the morning star
Now drives before him all his glittering flock,
And bids them rest within the ●old unseen
Till with his whistle Hesper call them forth.
Now Titan up and ready calls aloud,
And bids the rolling hours bestir them quick
And harness up his prancing foaming steeds
To hurry out the sun's bright chariot.
O now I hear their trampling feet approach:
Now now I see that glorious lamp to dart
His nearer beams, and all bepaint with gold
The over peeping tops of highest hills.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Trust you upon your word? Did not you promise to interpret? Here's linsey-woolsey ●ian, where every English thread is overcast with a thick woollen woof of strange words, which have so deep a nap, that the plain ground cannot be seen. I pray you what have you said all this while?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I have said but one word, lucefeit, ●t is morning.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: And could you not have told me that in one word, by bidding me good morrow?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I give no morrow unto thee, but to the Muses, and myself.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: I have as good part it h day light, as the best mincing muse of them all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Welcome fair light, most welcome unto me, when these thy beams reflect upon my book.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Now I understand you better. I hope he ●mend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O how it joys my watchful eyes and heart, to crop the first fruits of the virgin morn.

sp.speaker: Lal.
sp.p: Crop the first fruits of virgins ▪ I'll take heed of him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And spend that precious stock of common light
Upon this author's lines, and such bookware.
The morning is the muses gainest friend.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Surely this scholar loves to come first to school ▪

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O how my blood doth warmly sweetly thrill,
My senses lulled, my heart enwrapped with joy,
To see these plains, this fair two-headed hill,
Those bowers, these towers, those winding banks,
These shady laurels, and that temple gate
The seat, the throne, the nest, the rest, the school
Of great Apollo, and his darlings nine.

sp.speaker: Lala.
sp.p: Well, I see now it will be English. It shall go hard but I'll get a part amongst them. I'll into the tiring house, and scamble and wrangle for a man's part. Why should not women act men, as well as boys act women? I will wear the breeches, so I will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No court of King, no palace stately rich,
Though proud of marble feet and guilded head
Can outbid these for true and sweet content.
Let others grovel and embrace the earth,
(The earth the whole world's basest sediment)
Let them there dig their mother's bowels out,
And thence take gold (The earth's worst excrement)
Let muddy minds board up, and hug, and hid,
And sit upon the eggs of avarice:
Thence hatching vipers of their stinging cares.
Let others sell their lives away in sport,
Or play the parasites in fickle court.
Let others swell with greatness, burst with pride.
And others lusk and snort in lazy sleep,
Or drench and soak themselves in Bacchus' suds,
Or wallow in the mire of pleasures lewd:
These seats, these bowers, are to Philoponus
True pleasure, riches, honour, kingdom, rest.
But now fair Phoebus with his rising rays
Strikes on his own bright temples battlements,
The watchword for the daily sacrifice.
The suns first heat, that warms this temples top,
Calls for the altar to be warm below.
Now now Musaeus his observant priest
With other serviteurs bestir them quick
To feed that never-ceasing sacred fire.
My part must be in that devotion,
To take from thence a blessing for the day.
Our actions hence have their prosperity,
By timely worshipping the deity.

sp.speaker: Amph.
sp.p:
What is he gone? I so. He keeps out wonted time, and now is well employed in doing sacred homage to Apollo. There lays he the foundation of his studious diligence. There sore he misses me, and says unto himself. Where is my Amphibius? Why keeps he not his accuostomed hour? What, shall I after Philoponus into the temple?
'tis with the latest now. And (To confess the truth) alas I dare not there appear to present myself before Apollo's altar. Nor have I now the boldness to look my dear Philoponus in the face. His settled countenance and grave gesture give a cheek unto my levity. His very silence reads unto me a lecture of reprehension. My passions so deep enthralled another way, bid me now rather to withdraw from such society, and hide myself in shades and groves, and solitude ▪

Alas Amphibius, though having tided himself to the mast of safety by the bonds of temperance, yet breaketh loose, and leaps into the sea of danger. Alas he cannot hold. This Sirens song is so attractive. I yield, I come and yet how can I? shall I run away from the worthy trade whereto I am bound apprentice? My name is enrolled in Apollo's register, and shall I raze it out, and be reckoned among the fugitives and renegadoes? Not so. And yet and yet it will be so. O how my very book seems now a burden unto me, and that which heretofore did elevate my soul, and give it wings to fly aloft, sweet contemplation of nature and of arts, that now alas lays on me the heavy load of upbraiding, I fly, I fly, I haste into thee by ways of these thickest groves
What dark some cave will give me shelter, and hide me from the light of mortal eyes, and of the immortal eye of this world the all-viewing Phoebus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And now methinks my spirits lighter are,
My soul more clear, my wits more active far
Since I received from grave Musaeus' hand
Apollo's benediction for this day.
sp.p: But where is my Amphibius? he promised to overtake me at this morning sacrifice. I hasted not, I did protract till Phoebus (Whose swift chariot no hand can stay) by his visible messenger called for our common duty and devotion.

What will he thus leave me alone? And yet even thus alone I am not. Nunquam minus solus quam cum solus. My books and meditations are my companions, that never fail me. With me they walk and talk, with them I rest at home: and other while when I travel abroad and converse with contemplation, how short and easy are the ways? yea, and how safe too? I can fear no the eves: the muses are my guard. And in very truth, what can the eves rob me of? My purse is light, and so my heart. My true riches treasured up in the cabinet of this breast, no lurching hand by stealth, no robbing rover by force can seize upon. My father hath no land to leave me. I think his mean estate is the better means of my happiness. This education which he affords me, I take for a more goodly and durable inheritance, then if he could have left me thousands of stocks and acres, without any bringing up in quality other than the gentle vanities of the times.
I envy not our spruce gallant jingle, that now forsooth scorns to be our schoolfellow any longer. Our sable robe is too homely for such gaudy butterflies.
But ho Philoponus whither dost thou range? These flies not worth the gazing on would seduce me out of my way. Away ye fluttering moths that fain would eat holes in the muse's robes.

Come wi● philosophers, come soul-plying orators. Nay to you I come; ye are my home, the true centre whereon my circling thoughts do rest. O mellifluous Tully. O streaming overflowing Ovid. O majestic Virgil. Grave Quintilian. Sententious Isocrates. Virtuous Seneca plentiful Plutarch. Profound Aristotle. Divine Plato. My solace, my guides, my instructers. O how your words distil into my thirsting soul, like to immortalising nectar.
Where left we last, sweet numbersome Isocrates?
O here, where thy lamp burneth bright.
〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉. Isocrat ad demonic.

This rule he delivers, think not to walk unseen when thou goest about any wickedness. For, though no man over-spy thee, thine own conscience keeps watch over thee. O the divine power of unbred conscience? Suitable to this is that of Seneca. Quid prodest non habere conscium habenti conscientiam? When Amphibius and I discoursed on this point at our private reading of Seneca, I remember how affectionately he would take the book into his bosom, and hug it, and protest that this one sentence is able to make us honest men. I will seek him out, that we may mutually kindle the sparks of conscience in our breasts,Exit.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Come away, come away.
Now clearly shines our shroving day.
Now are we fresher then in may,
Come, come away, our work is play.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.l: Apollo's solemn shroving feast,
Inviteth all from cast to West:
Come away, come make no slay,
No muse's friend can say us nay.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Apollo's yearly visitation
You know begins with proclamation,
Come mouthing Praeco, clear thy threat,
And chant the law in twanging note.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: O yez.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: He may cry oh yez till his belly burst. But, for ought I see, here's nobody to hear him.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: nobody ? That's none of our fault. All may come if they will, Apollo keeps open sessions. Look Praeco, canst thou see no audience?

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Nor man, nor mouse.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: If I see anybody , I would I were the muse's tankard-bearer.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: That's a punishment would no near to beggar you. For I am sure you would be licking up the Castalian drops that fall from the muse's tankard, and that would make you turn rhyming poet.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p:
I wish I had no better fortune, than to be a pretty water poet with a high forehead like I. T. that acts the swan by the banks of Thames in England.
I cursed myself happily.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: What is that acting the swan?

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I mean the swans, or goose's broad paddle feet, the natural prime pattern of the artificial oar.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: O que, I have him. He means the easy smooth voluminous untaught poet, that will row you over the Thames in rhyme, every stroke of his oar cuts out the capering feet of his verses.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Would we had him in Parnassus. He would stroke our mistresses the muses gently with his oar, and make their worships very merry, with his paper Wherry.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Paper Wherry? you mean by a metaphor, that his papers and verses carry a man's attention as smooth as a wherry.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: No, I mean his sailing in a paper boat, and poetising upon that and other his own adventures.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: He shall have my voice to be admitted into the third form of the usher's part in Parnassus' school, if he will lay his claim for it in solemn session.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.l: I'll register his name with a witness,
If he bring evidence of his fitness.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: This poetical boat hath made us sail out of our way. Drudo look down there between the temple and the hill, see if you spy anybody . And you Praeco, put on you spectacles, and look into the grove.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Neither bird nor feather.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Neither fish nor fin.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: We shall forfeit our liberties, if we can get no audience to listen to our proclamation. Praeco, up that bank, nay mount up that tree.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: It is more wholesome mounting that one tree, than some other three trees, compact in a Greek pee.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Seest thou anybody now?

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Abundance. O multitude! O variety!

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: What be they? discover them to us.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Men. Boys.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Who else?

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Item there be others, shall I discover them too?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: I am too bashful to uncover them. They are women.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: On prattling preco.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: Men, women, young, old, black, white, blue, sitting, standing, looking, laughing.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Whence thinkest thou come they, and what would they?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: No doubt they come a shroving to Apollo. If the Muses have not provided for their palate, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: It is hard to dress a shroving dish to please so many several tastes. They must be content to take such as they find or bring, like good gossips.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Well sir preco, for the first service, let them hear the proclamation. Begin.

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: O yez, o yez, o yez.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: All manner of scholars and students

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p: All manner of scholars and students

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: With their retainers

sp.speaker: Preco.
sp.p:
With their retainers and appurtenances that hold or pretend to hold ‑ in capite ‑ any learning, art or science ‑ of the grand lord our sovereign Apollo ‑ or of the mean land. Lady's ‑ the nine sister Muses ‑ or of any of them ‑ let them appear this day in the
afternoon ‑ at the great laurel on the western top of Parnassus ‑ there to do their homage suit and service ‑ and to give account to our said lord Apollo ‑ or to his high steward muss us ‑ of the expense of their time ‑ in their several trades ‑ and mysteries ‑ of the Muses ‑ also there and then ‑ upon the oath of homagers ‑ strict inquiry and search is to be made ‑ concerning all encroachments ‑ intrusions ‑ and nuisances ‑ done or suffered to be done ‑ upon the inheritance ‑ rites and royalties ‑ pertaining to the manner of Parnassus ‑ all that will accuse, shall be heard ‑ and all that will answer ‑ shall have liberty ‑ of defence ‑ by themselves ‑ or by their counsel ‑ learned in the muse's laws.
Keep Apollo's peace, and then he end the muses prosper you.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Come down now Praeco from your chair of stare, and walk with us mortals here below.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Lauriger think you that any of those, whom Praeco overviewed, will lay in any action at Apollo's court today?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Why not? perhaps some of them hold for life some paper tenement belonging to Apollo's ●nner. And thereupon may crave admittance to it others upon their experience may inform Apollo's jury what waste hath been made of the trees in Parnassus grove with cropping off laurel garlands to adorn the light head of every ballad belching Po●. Or what dilapidations have in process of time grown upon the muse's cells. So that Boreas whistles everloud in their ears when they are retired to contemplation.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: These and all other informations shall be surely heard. We know that is our lord Apollo's express mandate.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Now return we up the mount, and acquaint Mus●us what we have done. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Renowned father of fashions, count of courtesies, marquess of modern motions, Duke of debonair deportments, chief justice of gesticulations.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Go on with the alphabet of my titles. Comptroller.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I have it, comptroller of congoes, compactor of cringes, Fea● framer of ●ian phrases.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: O wonderful: this is a brave man. We have no such dainty words in our school.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Dainty? I tell thee, novice, we have store of this plumporridge at our house every day. (Little else.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Sirrah, you forget the titles given me by the great mogul, when I went ambassador to him from the King of Calecut, a golden trumpet sounded them in the Persian language.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: That trumpet could speak Persian well, I can hardly hit upon them in the original. Varletto, polmone, manigoldo.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You mask unknown, unseen. Descend I say to the apprehension of the base vulgar. Give us them in translation.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p:
Indoctrinate of young nobility. Accomplisher of King's courts, chief engineer of cap and knee. clock-keeper of 〈◊〉 and 〈◊〉, and finally, engrosser of all unsailable,
available addresses, garbs, faces, graces in all places.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: Yet gooder and gooder. O admirable! This man is for us to the heavens.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: It is well, somewhat towards the superlative of my worth and profession but imp. I like not that word finally. When you rehearse me before the lady muses, they will think we are at the wall, that thou hast told all my virtues, and offices. I tell thee, not thou, nor the loud long tongue blab ●ame, can give the inventory of my perfections. Thinkest thou with the small wherry boat of thy short memory, to arrive at the terra incognita of the virtues and endowments of mighty captain compliment?

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: O eloquence. I see now that Tully and Ovid are but cou●se w●e.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I tell thee, and thou shalt find, that tittle tattle Tully is but brown bread, if he be laid near our marchpane.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ergo therefore my nimble imp. Take away that padlock finally, and in stead of the aforesaid, add to the saggy end of my catalogue, that endless chain which the vulgar Gramatians call et caetera.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Indeed master I have heard you say, that you would have your title like the great western monarch's ●e, with a long tail behind it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: True: and therefore you know, the motto which I subscribe in banner is plus ultra.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: My sweet friend, master implement, you told me that you would speak —

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I marry, and so I do.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: For me to the mighty man. All you have yet said to him, is but in the vocative case. And that case makes no sentence, as I have learned when I was in the second form. You know I gave you ▪

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: What did you give me? Nothing but a dozen of rotten ●ke points. You must tag them better ere I t●e up your request.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: I le steal my mother's peacock, and bring it you.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: A peacock? That's well. You may make us latter by it; but you cannot make us prouder.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What talk you of a peacock?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Sir, this young gentleman presents you with a peacock. It ha● a tail ▪ he ha● a small request to your worship.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: I dare as well he hanged as steal the peacock. My mother loves it so well, and feeds it every day, and pricks the feathers of it in her sanne.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Where is this peacock?

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: What shall I dee? I have none.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I mistook a peacock for a woodcock.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: I have never a woodcock neither.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Sir he would fain present you with a woodcock every day. His suit is to be your scholar for an hour in a day. He would dedicate himself to fine fashions and quaint quallicoms.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What nobility? What achievements embolden him to ob● upon us with such a request? An hour in a day? I tell thee, young chicken, great princes have not made such a motion unto me without an ambassador, and a present of a gold chain, or diamond ring, or some such trifle.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: Woe's me! Alas. I have no hope now, I think I must e'en return to my old trade again, and repeat in nova sert animus, and tityre tu patulae. O sweet imp. Be my faithful implement to your master. I'll do any thing for thee, or for any of thy kin.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Will you steal me your father's dagger with the silver haste?

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: And my mother's silver bodkin too.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: They shall prick forward thy cause. I gallop to save thy life. I will beg a pardon for thee of this judge. Relent heroic spirit, relent. For my sake entertain master novice into your school.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou knowest our school is thronged. My hands are full. The truth is, my virtuous faculty, joined with a strange dexterity, is so attractive, that I have scholars come flocking unto me, not only from the theater and Venus' court, but also from Apollo's seminary. I swell, I swell with the stuffings of the grammar brood.

sp.speaker: Imp
sp.p: I am one of those that lest the fescue trade, to page it thus in state.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay, logic and philosophy doth often break up shop, and come to set up at my stall.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Indeed master of late we have had very good doings. The usher of our school has had for fees of young gentlemen at their entrance, above an hundred crowns within this 12. months, besides his yearly stipend.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: I'll beg hard, but I'll get a crown of my mother , and twelve pence for thee honest i● implement.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: As for money for stipend or entrance, I do not much stand upon it, neither would I take any, but that I will not embase my faculty?.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Indeed master, if you should not take some fair see, the gentlemen would not think it such a reputation to be your prentises.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Truly the more cost, the more worship. A wise saying. Write you that in your table book master novice upon my authority.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p:
And their parents would scorn our ware, and say
it were like stinking fish it hend of a market.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: Again for me good imp.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I pray you sir let him be admitted. He'll be content to stand next the door of our school. I warrant you sir, he'll be fed fat for a whole year, with two or three of the easiest plain tricks, of ●g the hat ▪ or the gambrel ●th hams, the man i'th toe, and the gridiron i'th forehead. He'll be pleased with these till he can come to higher points of the retort, the ●e, the catastrophe, the antistropho.

sp.speaker: C●p
sp.p: I could be content to enrol him in our petty form, but that I doubt some exceptions will be taken at the confluence of so many of that tribe, to our part. Master Philoponus a sour stoical scholar, told me to my teeth, that Apollo should be complained unto, and I accused of robbery, for stealing away his best hopes.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Sir, I see no reason but you may entertain him as well as another. One stone more will not make the boat sink.
One kernel more put in the sack
Will not break the mrs' back.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: Good sir consider of me. Though I be not born to so much land as master Gingle my form-fellow, yet I shall learn by tricks as well as he. There is Mumble and Tristram, trump, and Jobbart, and nimble Nichol. I see not, but I may leave the satchel as well as they, and turn fine gentleman.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p:
Indeed they have profited very well with us. For they have torn out the leaves of all their books to light tobacco pipes, and they can imme, and effame, and resume with gentle postures master nimble can at one time, and with one hand put his off hat
with his right hand in due circumference, and brandish a battoon in's left hand, and suck a fuming tobacco pipe in's mouth without any hand, all at once.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: They say th● old grey beard Mus●us sets up inquisition, and ●at Apollo keeps court today. My sweet Siren sent me word this morning, that I know not how many of us should be indicted for encroaching upon Apollo's liberties.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: Indeed sir, an't please you, this Philoponus is the best scholar among us, but he is but a tell tale. There can't one of us play the tron't, or run away from school for recreation, or so, but presently he tells Musaeus of it. But I care nor, I had rather stick to you, and show Apollo a fair pair of heels.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: He that sticks to us must bring some glue: and money is a binder.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Imp. Are these young man's friends rich? Will they lard us with a fat pension?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: His father's but a plain farmer; but he's called the rich Chuff●. He keeps three ploughs, and fourteen yoke of oxen.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: But will his oxen give down their milk?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Faith his mother will stroke hard for it. She is a gentlewoman o'th' left side. I have heard her say, that she would like her son better in a scarce and ruffled boots, then in a gown with a fardel of books.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Well said, enough. You young man. My servant hath entreated hard for you. I am content to entertain you upon probation.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p: I am overjoyed, overjoyed.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Overjoyed? What a plain packstaff phrase is that? you must sublimate your joy in triumph thus. Hold me down lest I hit my head against a cloud.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.p:
Hold me down lest I hit my head against a cloud.
O what a brave world is this, all made of oatmeal: I'm now in the way of preferment and gallantry. I'll presently run to my mother for some cash for my entrance. I'm all now for masks, revels, courtship . Poor Apollo farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Sirrah Imp. I honour thee with thanks, a whole bushel, heap measure.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Ay, with such light co●e and husks am I said.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I enrich thee with thanks. Thou hast brought a pretty fat fowl to our net.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: We shall make him a flat fool.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Is not the hour come appointed by me to give access and interview to sir Orgolio?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Yes sir, the sun and clock says so. (And my clock tells me it is breakfast time. If I could tell where to lunch.)

sp.speaker: Comp
sp.p: Why then Vamos. I set my legs in due array, and march on foot down to the plain.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: So you had need. For all your horses have ten toes. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Amphibius solus.
sp.p: Or this, or that. This is my duty. So. And though so, yet why not rather that? I oh that mine inclination draws me. O strange monster, worse than ever nature did bring forth. A man in whom the light of reason shines, to walk in the cloudy night of tempestuous passions, to live at once in two contrary elements. Glorious Apollo I fain would still remain chine. And yet. And yet sweet Hedone, I cannot divorce myself from thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Parnassus plains. I he banks of Hippocrene, the laurel grove, all walked, all searched by me: and yet I find him not. O here not hoped, yet now found. Found? Is this he? Is this my Amphibius? Where art thou? Who art thou? Look up and show thy friendly brow. I hope no distaste estrangeth thee from thy Philoponus. What have we here: the walking ghost of Amphibius? Where is his soul, his life, his look, his speech?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: A wandering soul.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Wandering? I know no by way can call thee off from me. These groves, these banks, and shades, oh how oft have they been companions and witnesses of our friendship, and discourses of earth, of sea, of stars, of spheres, of motions, of rest, of beasts, of plants, of all dame natures works, and wondrous art, by which this all stands thus composed, and framed in most exact proportion. Awake I say, the muses call us to our task.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Worthy Philoponus. I love thee. I admire tho●. I envy thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I know thou canst not envy me. Thy heart is so generous, and my worth so mean, thou lovest me I know, for the parity of our dispositions and studies.

sp.speaker: Amp
sp.p: Would I were like thee now, as heretofore I have been, then should I not be thus dashed with shame.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What Amphibius, you are always modest. Hic virtutis colour. Blushing is virtues scarlet robe.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Alas, I am now like a cropped flower, which fades and hangs the head, I am pulled from the stalk on which I grew.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What blast hath thunder-stricken thee? Whence art thou fallen?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I must untwist.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: I hope, not from our bond of friendship.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: No: but from my bond of service to Apollo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thou from Apollo? First may the stars be plucked from heaven. Why but how?

sp.speaker: Amp
sp.p: In a word, I am turned soldier.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Soldier? Which of the furies plucked thee from our wonted peace and quiet in Apollo's service, now to pitch thy tent in Mars's field?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O how the drums and trumpets sound alarum. What strokes, what shrieks, what fierce encounters, wounds and deaths!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O tragedy! What scene is this? On what stage dost thou tread?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Alarm, alarm, to war. I fight, I fight.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I must maintain the quarrel on both sides.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Both sides? Who are the combatants?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Amphibius, and Amphibius. Never till now a true Amphibius as I am ▪ Apollo's and thine. I walk and march with thee, I fight under the muse's colours against ignorance, idleness and voluptuousness. But as I am another self, my left side walks another way. O force. O compulsion. I yield.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What force compels?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Fatis agimur, cedite fatis.

The destinies are powerful. If the fates say I, who
dares say no?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Our fates? Speak right, and say, our faults. They overrule and overturn us, when we are willing to be conquered, and then to colour our follies, we put on the mask of tragic exclamation upon our stars, our fates, our cross inexorable adamantine destinies.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Far easier is it to mock my misery then to cure it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Cure it? I will cure it. Let me feel thy pulse. O what boiling and beating waves of passion! W● thou calm them?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O could I! or couldst thou my Esculapius?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Recipe a biletto or tailor's bodkin; make but one eyelet hole under the left pap, three inches deep: your blood would be cooled; and you shall fall into a sweet sleep, and presently be transported into the Elysian fields. Probatum est.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Facile est miserum irridere.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Not I, but — you fate mongers teach you this. But in earnest I advise thee thus. Give over parling and combating: blow away your enemy out of the field with one blast. One word will do it.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What potent charm is that? I pray you teach it me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Only this stoutly said n●lo.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Oft have I thought and said it, but another word crowds in withal, and makes a counter charm. Volo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What? do you blow hot and cold at once, at once will and nill?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Vos testor omnes calites, hoc quod volo, me notte.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O sir, do you think Medea a fit pattern for you? Have you no better a mistress to instruct your wavering soul, then monstrous Medea?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yes, another mistress overawes me, more powerful than that enchantress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Overawes? O faint fondling, not worthy to march under the muse's banner, whose escutcheon is virtue argent, crowned Or. and the two supporters, winged victory, and winged all-eyed, all-eared, all-tongued fame.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: When this all-conquering Queen, sends forth her mandates, alas virtue melts into an aerial contemplation, and fame vanisheth into an empty sound.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What mandates other than usurped tyranny? What conquests other than by voluntary yielding to false allurements?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O valiant sir, can I, can you, can any mortal wight stand out and rebel when he is apprehended by this Queen's writ?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What writ? what arrest? you need not obey it. At lest you might lurk and withdraw yourself, and make them return a non est iuventus:

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O but these arrests do not so much command by authority, as convince and persuade by argument and reason.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Reason? what other reason then ut cum ratione insanias, that you may be reasonably raving mad?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Tu si hic esses, aliter sentires, the case would be altered, and you would plead as hard on my side.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Then let all the nine muses hiss at me, and banish me out of Apollo's school.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: The Muses? Apollo's school? I tell you the arguments by which I am convinced, are translated out of the records of the Muses, and cite everywhere Apollo's parliaments.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
What are these forged patches which plead their workmanship from the muse's looms? Have you
been weaving them in your sequestered studies?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Alas not mine, but on higher hand hath spun and twisted them. The Queen herself vouchsafed with her own wit and hand to compose this sovereign Nepenthe to embalm my soul in most desirable content. Queen Hedone herself wrote this large mellifluous letter to me, poor me. I thought she had not known me: but (Oh generous sweet graciousness) to this mean neglected Amphibius, she (That high and mighty sovereign of delights) sent this amiable garland of choicest flowers, culled by her own delicious hand; that hand, which the chiefest poets labour to paint cut, and the highest gods affect to kiss.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O how poetical you are grown, and fantastical? I think that paper hath infected you. But by what hand was it conveyed to you?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: By whom, but by her worthy maid of honour dame Siren, whose voice with one warble can thaw the most frozen affections

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay then I perceive he is handsomely caught.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I pray you view these lives. You will confess they are strong lines.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I have heard of strong lines, admitted by weak judgements, and derided by the judicious.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I pray you read. Else you rob me of my defence, and yourself of care pleasing ▪ soul-conquering suavity!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: To my not so dear, as worthy to be far dearer, Amphibius the flower of youth —

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: (Meaning me.)

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Honour and envy of his rank. —

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: (Meaning me, very good still)

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Accomplisher of virtues —

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: (Oh complete!)

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: In nothing wanting, but that he is indebted, —

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: (Yet she does not arrest me for money debt, no)

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Indebted to himself, in infinite sums of most currant delights, over churlishly neglected by him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Had these title been of my own devising, modesty would not have suffered me, to hear them read. But what Queen Hedone says, is a law; and it is a part of my obedience to accept the honour she confers upon me by her own hand. She trusteth no secretary when she writes to me. I think the muses will woo me for copies of this letter, they will imitate it, when they sing hymns in praise of Apollo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O forgery oh foppery!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Why? what?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thinkest thou that Queen Hedone wrote this letter to thee? I think she never heard of Amphibius.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Why? Am I not in the endorsement? I never heard of any other Amphibius. I will be this Amphibius till you find another Amphibius.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: See how thy good nature is wrought upon. This inscription is none of Queen Hedone's hand. Seest thou the character nothing a kin to the letter within

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Perhaps endorsements and names of note, are written in another hand for excellency. That is the court style.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let me tell thee a short tale. Thou hast heard of Burching-lane in London.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: London? Where's that? In England?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: So. And there are many volumes of apparel made at large by guess for no man, and for every man, for all, whom they may fit, or who will buy them.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What then? I buy none there.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: An honest rural guest coming thither, is hailed into a shop, and cared with a suit which though too wide, too long or short, he's persuaded 'twas made for him and none else, he pays, and goes, and after finds it shrinks.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What's this to me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Yes to thee. Mutato nomine de te fabula narratur. Thou art this new come guest, gazing on and admiring the varnished wares, set out in the deceitful shop of Hedone. She cuts out and tacks together, large declamations in folio. In laudem voluptatis. These she sends abroad by the end of her broker Siren: who, loaden with these blank letters, rambles up and down: and, when she lights upon any credulous soul, presently she adds an endorsement, and makes the receiver believe that Queen Hedone herself doth woo him. Against the concourse of this solemn day this Siren, hovering here for gain, now seizeth on thee. And thou believest that this paper garment was cut out and sowed and laced for Amphibius. If she meet with me, verily I shall have another the same letter, endorsed, to her dear, her only dear Philoponus. Then shall I be the flower of youth, and what not?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Admit sir this, that my name, was put in by the bearer upon general instructions only. Yet the powerful contents of the letter enforce in themselves the conclusion of my yielding.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thy yielding? And why not mine as well?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yes brother, and thine, and any's else, whose heart is not hewn out of a marble rock. Mine is of flesh, I call a woman mother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
I am of the same mould with thee. But I bethink
myself, why hath reason the sceptre in her hand, if rebel passion may be suffered to crowd into the throne.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: True, no oracle more certain. But alas. But I know not what within this melting breast cries out louder, and says, Amphibius, thou shalt now to this case dispense with those severe rules.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Where is thy logic? thy philosophy? Art thou an orator to persuade others to that which they know not, and canst thou not persuade thyself, in that which thou acknowledgest?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Nay, the arguments used by Hedone, are not emptily blown up with passion, but soundly grounded on philosophy, logic and oratory. S●en told me that her lady Hedone is near allied to Manto, Cassandra, Aspasia, and the ancient Roman Tanaquil. That this Hedone, better than Lesbian Sappho, might pretend to be the tenth muse.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why then comes she not now to Apollo's court at this solemn assembly, to lay in her claim for it?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Siren tells me, she had done so, but that she knew not of the set day, and now resideth in one of the fortunate lands in the Atlantic sea far oft from Thessaly. And besides all this, she is invited to a feast of four or five gods by Mercury into Ethiopia.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Such draff of si●ens by thy feast.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: For the cause of her absence I pass not much but I'm sure she's learned, and deeply read. That s●ee shows by the reasons and authorities heaped in her letter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What slout reasons? What authorities?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Even those which we read and admire in Apollo's school. What say you to Tully, Plutarch, Aristotle, Seneca, Socrates, Horace, etc.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: I am sure these afford impenetrable armor against the assaults of Hedone. And now are they brought on the other side against their wills?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Read but this line here in the bottom of the second page. Attend what your 〈◊〉 Tully saith, Dandu● aliquid atat●. Non s●mper ●ncat ratio, etc.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: This time and place s●s not to examine these particulars. Come let's to the laurel grove. There will we gauge to the bottom this farthel of false wares.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: One tells me I must study next my heart. That troubles my brain too much. Another tells me 'tis good to eat bread and butter next my heart. That fumes fumes into my head too much. And to say the truth, my stomach is not yet up. For I'm but new up myself, and I hope that will not be so saucy as to tread on his master's heels. But I say still, 'tis best playing next ones heart. That is to me both study and breakfast. Once again cross and pile, handy dandy, which hand will you have?
sp.stage: He plays two gamesters, and wrangles. —
sp.p: Oh for some companions. O for some good play fellows! Gingle he's grown so proud, he tells me he's not for boys play now. And slug I could not get him up. I bounced with my bag of counters against his door. And he answered me nothing but whough, pugh: he outsnorts nine horses, and outsleeps ten dormice. I will go find out novice. He's a young fat gosling to pull. Exit.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: When we had signified to our lord Apollo our publishing of his mandates, he was pleased to say that there was never more need of warning a court, than now, that abuses and usurpations have crept into his dominions. And therefore he charged us that this inquiry should be more strict than heretofore. Intra● Siren.
But look you now. There is one of the worms and caterpillars of our harvest.

I know her, though I never saw her before. By her fawning gesture and inchanting wand, she's that famous infamous Siren, which so troubles and bewilders some of our society. She hookes at all she meets. It's marvel if she reach not at me.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.l: To thee, renowned Lauriger,
I come a happy messenger,
From Hedone, Queen Hedone, sweet Hedone,
The goddess of delight and pleasure,
The life of life, the worl is best treasure,
Perform what I advise,
And thou shalt be more wise,
than all the rest that follow
Your mighty god Apollo.
Apollo's task torments your brains,
Abates your spirits, dries your veins.
Vain is your labour little profit,
No quiet by it, no end of it.
O cast away that laurel bow,
And crown thy head with roses now,
Now whilst thy frolic youth gives leisure
To bathe thyself in choicest pleasure.
Thy time doth go,
As river's flow.
Ere long, you know,
Grey hairs will grow.
Then shalt thou sigh, and say with tears,
Why lost I so my youthful years?
My spring is past, yet fain I would,
(But cannot) bud in winter's cold.
Come then before age bids good night,
Spend youthful day in sweet delight.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Is this the lecture you read to us? Is this all you can say? A flourishing glozing poetical theme, that hath neither truth nor substance in it. An empty sounding painted drum, fit for children to hear and follow with their rattles and hobby horses. Go Gill flirt, go set up your pedlars shop in Venus' court. There shall you have those that will dance to your music.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.l: No man so learned, wise, or strong,
But may be conquered by my song.

sp.speaker: Laur
sp.p: I can hear thee no longer. Avant thou Circe. Thinkest thou to transform me into a swine? I fly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p:
If he gone? I will not leave him so. A letter
from the goddess herself may pierce deeper with him, as it did with Amphibius. Exit.

div.head: Actus tertius. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Mistress indulgence Gingle, John Gingle her son, jug rubbish her maid.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Jug rubbish, what, jug rubbish. Come and bring his girdle.

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.p: Here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Have you warmed it?

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.p: I can find none but seacole fire to warm it:

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Out upon thee slut seacoal? I cannot abide to have any of that brimstone fume to come about the body of my child. Go kindle some charcoal, and warm it well on both sides. Exit jug.
What mother can think it any pain to bring forth so precious a fruit? O my living walking joy, thy father's picture, and thy mother's self, why shouldst thou be weaned from my lap?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Sweet mother. If I were to choose a mother,
Thou and no other
Should be my mother.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Sweet child, when thou speakest, methinks the muses, if there were nine times nine of them, are but oysterwomen and kitchinsluffe.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Honourable mother indulgence, I must be no more prentice to Apollo's trade. Must I?

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: No my child, thou art in a better trade. We are higher flown now.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p:
I like this new master better than Musaeus. We
have no terrible sceptre shaken over us in the captain's school.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Out upon that bloody butcherly weapon. What a base thing it is, that a man should be armed against children? What natural mother can suffer her own flesh and blood to be torn by these black gown? Cannibals? He that rancheth the flesh of my child, had as good kiss —

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Mother, I have heard that he was hanged that invented burch.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Ay, and he that invented books escaped by burning in the hand. Redit jug.

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.p: I have almost scorched my fingers with warming it:

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Shrink in while I buckle it, that you may be gaunt and fine in the waist.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Mother. When you go in your coach up Parnassus hill, I must sit in your lap, must I not? and hold Tisby's left ear in my hand with two fingers thus must I not? O it is the finest puppy.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Ay, darling, and hold my fan in thy other hand, and sometime shake it at the common people when we pass by them.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Indeed mother, these are very gentlemanlike feats. I wonder the captain has not read any lecture to me of them.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: The captain is to teach thee more soldierlike tricks. I can teach thee these at home. Why jug do you see how the rose is ruffled on the top of his spur-leather, set it better with your poking finger. (Valour.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: He has already taught me one soldier trick of

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: What is that my sweet baby?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p:
When you are in your coach, if any horses, though never so well bred (Except the horses of Apollo's own chariot) shall presume to take the wall or upper
hand of any of your coach-horses, I must straight leap out of the coach, and with my poniard stab one of those uncivil horses through both the ears at once.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: I see captain compliment is an excellent master, he will make my child be called the son of Mars and Bellona. He deserves more stipend than I allow him for thee. Why son Gingle, this will be an action not only of valour, but of honour and duty to me.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: If I thus venture myself in duty to you, I pray you forget not your duty to me. You know my father's a man of great worth, and lands, and I am his heir apparent.
I pray you in good company, call not me plain son Gingle, or son John, or so, but master John, or master Gingle my son, or so. Others will do me the more honour for it.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: True my honourable child master John jingle or so. If thou beest used with such respect by me, how great honour will others yield me that bore thee? But son I doubt, if the horses be tall, thou canst not have them by the ears with thy poniard. Thou shall ▪ have thy father's long guilt rapier. That will reach them, unless they fly as high as Pegasus.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O for that rapier. If I had it, the captain would teach me in one day and a half, how to wear it, how high the pummel must sit above the chape, and how to wind it about when I salute.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p:
I prithee, sweet son, let me see thee once act the fine gestures, which the captain hath taught you. You do them by yourself alone in the chamber, and the door shut to you. I looked in yesterday at the keyhole, and methought it did me good to see thee repeat some of them in the presence of a candlestick,
and bedstaff that were set upon the table.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Are you guised of that mother? That is a secret, which the captain tells me, that I must show my feats to none till I am well practised. And another secret, better than that, is, in my private practising to set up imagined spectators for the whetting of my care and diligence. And therefore sometime I set upon my table, a full auditory of cushion, candlestick, Slippers, bellows, and chamberpot.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: See my son master Gingle, see what wrong you do me then. You will not allow me that favour, which you do to your bellows, and that which is below bellows.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman mother, I cannot do withal as yet. You know when you put me to this mighty master, you charged me upon your blessing to obey him, and follow his instructions, rather than the precepts of Musaeus or Apollo himself. But by the next month, I think the captain will give me leave to repeat my postures before you. I will do your mothership the favour to be in the first form of my spectators.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Next month? I cannot tarry till next day. Hold, here's a crown, carry to him for his favour, to make me a spectator without delay. It may be in your repeating, I shall teach you some gestures that the captain thinks not of.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: But mother, I hope you will not fail my master captain. You will be a suitor to Apollo for him, that he may continue his school of fine feats here near our door.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p:
Why child to that end have I called to have my coach made ready. Apollo's great hall is almost a flight shot off on the top of Parnassus, I cannot get up
thither without my four fourfooted prancers. Jug bid my coachman lay the coach bed backward, for we are to climb the hill. But I must in to dress me better, and set my face in court fashion. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Valorous sir, I pray you clear your brow. What cloud of discontent envelopes your heroic soul?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell thee 〈◊〉. I am duloros●, I am fumbled and fuddled, and stu● with two horns, grief and anger.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Hath s●●ned on you?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Now b●y I have her love and shall.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: (Well you may, you pay dear for it.) I hope sir you are not angry with me sir, your diligent implement.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: With thee? Thou shrub, thou scrub. Thou art below my wrath. The thunderbolt of my indignation, where it bolteth forth —

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: (My masters bolt is soon shot)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Bestuds the tallest oaks: it strikes not at such daisies as thou art, dandiprat.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: But master, if you'll give me leave, I dare ask who dares make your choler boil.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Sir boy, I'm angry with myself, and with a certain knight errant.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p:
Errant? An errant ass he is, that angers you. I'll lay my cap against my dinner (That's odds against a cheese paring) some knight has taken the wall of you,
and has challenged you into the field. And now methink , your anger makes you tremble.

sp.speaker: Comp. implement
sp.p: Learn this of me, no fear, but anger, makes men of valour tremble. For anger is the whetstone of fortitude, as sometime said sir Harry Tottle, my fellow knight and philosopher.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Woe to that knight, which conjured up that spright. Your angry spirit will not be conjured down, without blood shed. (The reason is, my master loves black puddings well.) But I pray you master, what knight? I'll be your second. My keen weapon feeds on bloodshed. But I shall have the worst in this bloody combat. (For nothing but the pudding skins and knotted threads, will fall to my share.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Didst thou mark even now when sir Orgolio came to me, desirous to be intolled my scholar?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I remember you went aside: but I could not perceive so much as an angry look between you.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: No. He was well pleased: but little to my case. The truth is, for fashion's sake, I had him to dinner against tomorrow at my lodging. And he. —

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: (He's enjoined penance by it)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: And he, like an unnurtured swain, —

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Would have you dine with him.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: No. No, imp. The swain accepted my proffer. Was I so kind and generous to invite him, and he be so unkind as to come?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Indeed that's plain country fashion, unfit for us.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell thee imp I hate him for it, and if he come, I'll sauce him for it. He shall dine's last. I'll temper the salad with my own hands.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p:
So you had need, (For we have no co●ke to do it. My master and I are all the officers i'th house) but master, is it so hateful and deadly to accept
a dinner at another man's table? How are you then alive? Methinks the lords and knights should have poisoned you long since.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou hast a pestilent cross witted brain. I think thy conceits do caper the cross point within thy pericranium. But see how far thy reach comes short of mine.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: (I me sane to reach far●e sometime, else I may starve.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Such young cubs as thou, though wily, yet cannot extinguish. I extinguish t●us upon the point. A man may be said to eat another's meat upon invitation, or sans invitation. Which the vulgar call not invited ▪ I walk the second way. I will not be invited. My worth, my gentle faculty, my brave profession, they are the orators, the messengers, the sergeants that invite, and drive, and draw me to the tables of the best.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I would not be that porter that should keep you out (In a cold hungry day when we have fasted over night.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell thee, my presence adds honour to the place where I come. Where ere I dine, my virtues pay my share, and where I sit, I leave behind me the sweet perfume of courtesy.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: (A sweet perfume quoth he. He has forgotten at the French ordinary when two lackeys fell out, and one of them drew his poniard, who was't fell in a swoon and left such a perfume behind him, that the chamberlain spent six pence in frankincense.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
But ho, where is this fly? My imp. I do vouchsafe to stoop so low as to ask thy counsel. It enhanceth my wisdom, to choose such a servant, as is able to advise his master. The wise commanders in
the wars sometimes listen to the counsel of a common soldier, as dan Plato saith in his politics. What sayst thou imp. What shall I do to beat this dog from my door, it he come tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Let him come, and bark for hunger: the cudgel of my wit shall ●ang him away

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: So you 〈◊〉 my honour, faithful imp. To thee I leave this 〈◊〉, but 〈◊〉 I would know the medicine whereby thou wouldest purge this distemper out of me.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I was now tempering and preparing it. List how the hammers ●eate in the tongue of my brain. Thump. I'll none of that. Thump again. I like that better.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I long to see the birth of the child of thy brain.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: What if you send him word, that this day upon Apollo's call, the whole academy of virtuous students arriving here, the captain of your complemental school count Pacheco gi●o, takes up the chief inn in Parnassus.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O, at the sign of the flying horse Pegasus.

sp.speaker: Imp
sp.p: And there makes his pro●●ast with a mask, that must last till midnight.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I prithee do not hold me till midnight in the unmasking thy advice. What's this to me and sir Orgolio?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: And thereupon that the foresaid don hath over entreated your honourable worship to be the herald and Earl marshal to set every guest in● place, and every di● in● rank.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: That none can do but I, and those that learn of me.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Otherwise the cooks and sewers will make a ●ay with spi● and chopping knives: and among the guests there will be a mortal fight for precedency in place.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Well said my boy. I have it now. Therefore ergo. the exclusion is, that, as he would prevent murder, he expect not to have me stay at home that day.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: That is a charitable exclusion, and tends unto the preservation of Apollo's peace.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: But how if sir Orgolio say then he'll come thither too, and be my shadow there, and play the under ▪ marshal at my beck?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: He cannot be so uncivil, as to intrude, unbid, uncouth, unkissed.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: He that would be so uncivil, as to come invited, I dare not trust him where he is not called.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Let him come at his own peril, yet our house shall be thus acquit of him.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What if he return me word that he will come and dine with me next day?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: If so, then rather than fail, I'll blaze it all abroad, that your lodging is set on fire with 〈◊〉 of whole shoals and legions of provision for entertainment.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: That will be for mine honour, that my great chamber of entertainment is in combustion with the fumes of my hospitality.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: And for your thrift too, that none shall hereafter think to be your guest. (Great chamber? We have never a ●come bigger than a cobbler's stall; and as for fire, it blazes no further than a tobacco-pipe with us.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I say none but the son of a cobbler would be so uncourteous, as to reply against this answer; and none so witless, if ever he refined his brains with tobacco

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O how hast thou raised up my heavy heart, I warrant I weigh ten pound lighter than I did ere while.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p:
Lighter ten pound of lead. (For I never now him weigh heavy ten pound of silver. I think the
fairies run away with his money. He sucks the young gentlemen's purses, and yet we starve at home.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Now is the time that master Gingle is to meet with us on Parnassus downs to act his trampling part Vamos. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lauriger solus.
sp.p: A man had need to have a long fork, to keep off this Siren. After I had repulsed her insinuating song, she follows me still, and delivers me a letter, sent from the lady Hedone (To me, she says) and shows a fair endorsement in guilded letters. To the grand supporter of Apollo's court, Lauriger. And so forth as follows in that un●st title, when I had read the superscription, she by violence would needs embrace me. I vouchsafed not so much as to open the letter. Whereupon with hateful heart, and spiteful look, she vowed revenge. Now who but she has contrived to catch me in a snare. A message is brought to me by a seeming friend, o● proffering a pension from captain compliment, to procure a patent from Apollo to hold on his apish trade within these walls.

The broker told me, that, of Lauriger, that gold would make me auriger, that this captain fetching over divers of our younglings, and cheating them of their money, we, by way of reprisal, may take this passion, that it is no bribery to receive it, but an act of justice: that he that robs a thief, hath earned not only pardon, but also praise.

Now Lauriger summons his wits, and says, this is a trap to bring thee in disgrace, and to endanger thy office in Apollo's court. ●ay a straw there Lauriger. Consider that this bragging hobby-horse lives but in all hungry fashion. All he can scratch by cheating, he spends on that witch Siren. He every quarter to allow a pension of five crowns, that can scarce allow himself five dinners, or an honest flock-bed to repose his vaulting bones? Lay another straw th●e, Lauriger, ●t his straw m●sse.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I think I rose not on the right side today. I have rambled up and down, and can get no playfellows.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay this snare which they have laid for me, whe● me the more to accuse them both anon at Apollo's judgement seat.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Novice is so taken up with the captain, that he cannot be for me all this day.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: First I will plead he is a corrupter of youth, and turns them from humane shape into baboons.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Will nobody take pity on a desolate gamester? Will you play with me? will you?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Secondly, he robs them of their patrimonies.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Come you it'h blue jacket, I'll try with you at this, or that, or these.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Thirdly, he pulls away the sweetest nothings from the muse's breasts.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: At length well hit, I have found now. Ho. Sir Lauriger, I challenge you at bull, bear, and horse.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You will be ho●st at school for this. Will not a snatch in the afternoon serve you, and then buckle to your book again, but you must lavish out the cream of the morning so prodigally, and hold on thus till noon?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I tell thee, I had rather have this then cream with sugar. I taste my play: all else is unsavoury to me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: If Mus●us hear of this, Apollo's curse will light upon thee.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Apollo is our great lord. And yet I have heard that he loves boys play, and therefore he still continues a boy.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Peace thou babbling ●aving tongue.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: What is he else? I am sure he has no beard.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Thou ignorant fondling, that is hieroglyphical. His beardless flourishing youth, signifies the never fading fame which is gotten by his service.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Ay, but sir, by your leave, I have read, that Apollo was wont to play at quoits.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: The gods may be said to quoit when they cast into the lap of fortune, the lots and fates of mortal men. This is the moral of it.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I say Apollo played at quoits, as we do. And his playfellow was young Cyparissus, a boy about my pitch and years, but that he had not so manly a look, as myself, but simpered somewhat womanishly.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Cyparissus that was turned into a cypress tree ▪

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Apollo played with him, by a good token, their quoits were knockers, heavier than horse shoes, I think. For the poor boy was brained with one of them.
sp.l: Doth not our Ovid Naso,
That never told lie, say so?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: A good token? that's a bad token.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: O how it grieves n●y heart to think of that honest lad. Ah poor Cyparissus. When I learned the lesson in Ovid, I could have corn that lease out of my book, for very grief, that such a mischance should fall out at the worthy exercise of quoiting. Out alas, if my trade did not employ me better, I could weep my pocket full.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: You may take a better lesson thence, then weeping. The meaning of that fable is, that shrewd hoys must beware of spending their time in play, lest some mischief befalls them: nay lest Apollo himself brain them.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: You construe false to us, so you do.
But I say still,
And so I will.
I gather thence and will lay odds,
That sport and play beseems the gods.

Else our good master Apollo would never himself have played at quoits in his own proper person, with a paltry boy, like one of us. I have writ this note in the margin of my book. And I think verily if Ovid were alive again, and should see my wholesome lines, he would turn them into verse, and add them to that story.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Ovid had never been so good a poet, if he had spent his school time idly in play as you do.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Ovid loved play well. I have heard that he played with Corynna.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: How this lad prates? Ludio I tell thee that was no boys play.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: By your leave sir, Ovid hath honoured my exercises. He describes in verse our boys play.
Parna tabella capit ternos utrinque lapillos,
sp.stage: In queis vicisse est continuasse tuos.
sp.p: Twice three stones, set in a crossed square where he wins the game
That can set his three along in a row,
And that is sixpenny moral, I trow,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: This boy consters that true, which many a man understood not. Verily thou readest books only where they speak of play.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I do not think that if he were here, he would entreat Apollo to play at quoits with me or check stone, or spurn-point.

Good sir Lauriger, you are better acquainted with Apollo then I. I pray you entreat him to play with me this great play day. This is his fat remedy at his shrovingfeast they say. I challenge him at all games from blowpoint upward to football, and so on to mumchance, and tick-tack.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: How this boys fancy makes him saucy. Is it not enough sirrah, that you trouble me thus with your idle chat, but you must be so bold with great Apollo? He thinks the gods can enjoy no greater bliss then gaming.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Sir, do you hear? rather than sit out, I will give Apollo three of the nine at tick-tack. I do not think but I shall take him at a why not every other game. His mind will be so on the Muses, and upon his verses.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Apollo and his Musaeus take you too often with a why-not at-school. You know what should follow thereupon. Why-not, etc.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p:
Threaten me not. I tell thee, no torture can make me bate an ace of my play. You would not think it, but, as I am true Ludio whensoever I am trembling under the hand of the executioner, if I do but think on my play, than even then, those back blows, (Which others think so rueful) seem to me nothing,
but threshing hens at Shrovetide. He that spends his life in play, keeps Shrovetide all the year.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Belike you think play to be Apollo's Shrovetide

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I that I do: else why play we now in honour of Apollo?

sp.speaker: Lau.
