sp.p: I tell thee this our play if it be weighed right, is three ounces study, and but one ounce play. This fla● of recreation is not kindled without a spark of diligence. Our playing now is a kind of study, whereas as thy seeming study is nothing but playing or plodding how and where and with whom to play. Thy trade is to be prodigal of (The chiefest riches which is in o● power) time. Thou art a very bankrupt of thy own time: and lovest to pull others into the same losses.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: What speak you of losses? He that loseth at o● time may win at another. I can tell you of o● young Oleo, he got of ganeo the elder, all his points hatband, garters, and a gold ring, and five crown in money; and yet in two hours to see to, see how fortune came with a windlass about again.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Peace thou brat, whose mouth is armed with bale of dice, instead of a stall of teeth. What pratest thou of recovering lost rings and money? The shi● wrack that thou makest is unrecoverable.
sp.stage: Nec revocare potes, qui: periere, dies
sp.p: Lost days can never be recalled. Time steals away, as thou art a stealer of time. See now how thou hast encroached upon my precious time, whilst I hear a● speak, with such a canker of good hours. Away away.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: You bid me away, because you dare not play with me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Dost thou dare me thou elf? I will.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p:
I know you'll venture no money, nor points.
must play with you for nothing. Come on therefore at hide and seek, or blind man buff.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Come, I will once boy it again at either for a crash

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Why then at blindman buff you shall be first blinded.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay sir boy, if you challenge and choose the game too, you must be first blinded. But what tools have we?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Borrow one of these gentlewomen's masks:

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay then you will look through the holes. Will you gull me so?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: If I once look through the holes, then say Ludio is set in the pillory. but rather than want ●ew, here take my garter, and tie my satchel about my face.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: O with what wicked bombast is his satchel slust? I thought it was not true begotten books, that made the belly of it swell so big.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: It has cast calf now. You must tie me to these winkers.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: I had rather tie thee to one of our school posts, or hang our great dictionary at thy heel, for a clog to keep thee from gadding to play.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Talk not to me of Dick snary, nor Richard-snary; I care not how little I come near them. But sir you must have this morris-bell tied to your point, that I may hear where you go. Else you will have too much odds of me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Will you make me act hobby horse, or master Gingle? For once I will.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Now that is on, come and tie me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: So, you are tied, now I must turn you about thrice. Sic deluditur ludre. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p:
I do not hear the bell. Lauriger stands still I
doubt. Nay gentle playfellow, you must stir up and down, ●e we shall have no sport.

sp.speaker: Sirea.
sp.p: I hope to find more game here. O yonder's a ●h gamester. I think he is caught in our net already. So, so, verily Cupid hath blinded him for our purpose.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: O I have him. I have him. But where is your bell? untie me now it is your 〈◊〉 to be blinded oh what ha●d 〈◊〉 undo me, undo me.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: I have but the undoing of many in my days. But I never met with so forward a guest, that would beg his own undoing.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I have over come it now. What now? He turned to she? Master Lauriger, methinks your looks are grown very long on the sudden. Has he served me thus?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: How well art thou served, when such a nymph is at thy service?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: If thou be at my service, s●ake thy silken coat, and golden band, against my garters and hat. Lift who shall deal.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: I thee, I use little plain dealing. I must shuffle and cut too.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Both? Nay that's against law.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: Yet will i deal plainly with thee. I have neither skill nor mind to play with thee.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Can any sweet nymph be a stranger to Ludio? I have heard that nymphs love to play at more games than I know.

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: I do not refuse, because thou art a stranger, but because thou art our friend; thou art ours already. What need we spend birdlime upon those wanton sparrows, that are in our cage already? S●t cousin Ludio, thou art a member of our family Queen he done gets good access by thee. Go on with all thy thrifty wares to get in more letters up in our trade. Go to sir Grobiano, make him pay for thy acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: Gentle goldilocks. I would do so, but that I am now employed against my wont in studying an oration to save my head from a blow, which Apollo's visitation may now bring upon me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Novice, you know you must appear too.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: I have cited him according to law.

sp.speaker: N●u.
sp.p: What is the matter, think you?

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: I heard a bird sing (Hark in your ear) that there's an accusation against you for misspending your time with captain compliment.

sp.speaker: N●.
sp.p: I do but as others do. I am not alone.

sp.speaker: ●nd
sp.p: What strange guest is yond? A female I think. Who but Siren that has made such turmoils here of late. Praco have you cited her?

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p:
She's in my ●owle, I'm glad I have met with her. Dame Siren, thou art indicted by the name of Siren for subverting Apollo's subjects; you must along with me, and appear to answer such matters
as shall be objected against you, on the behalf of our sovereign lord Apollo.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p: Thou arrest me, who have arrested thy betters? I tell thee, I will be there. I have good friends in Apollo's court. I will not be hired to tarry away. But before I go, I must deliver a message to you from a great goddess.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: A goddess to me?

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p: I●o thee, and thee, and to you all.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Say what thou must, or canst.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.l: Hedone, Queen Hedone, sweet Hedone,
Dame nature's care, and noblest birth,
The i●y, and crown of heaven, and earth,
The aim, and centre of desire,
The fuel of most sacred fire,
By me, and this, and this
She sends you all her bliss.
Among the gods she hath her place,
They all stand gazing on her face.
The clouds do from her presence fly,
'Tis sunshine where she casts her eye.
Where are she treads on earth below,
A rose or lilly up doth grow.
Her breath a gale of spi● brings:
Mute are the muses when she sings.
Whate'er she touches turns to nectar,
What man, but can, and must affect her?
No heart so hard, but needs must melt,
When once her kindly warmth is felt.
She, she vouchsafe, to call you to her,
And wooing prays you now to woo her.
By study soon, fresh youth doth break,
The fair grow foul, the strong grow weak:
Leave leave this musing bookish trade:
enjoy yourselves before youth fade.
Time must be gone,
Old age creeps on.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: She puts her message home, methinks .

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: I have arrested her; and I think she will arrest us.

sp.speaker: Novice.
sp.p: I like her song well, I'll get a copy of it. If Apollo give me leave, I will have more acquaintance with her. Methinks this Siren would make a good wife for my master, captain compliment, and so she shall be my mistress. O fair Hedone, sweet honey Hedone, more sweet than Marmalet, or Quidony.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Away thou glozing flatterer. We are no game for thee. Let us about our business. Praeco do your office, carry her away. Let her chant this song before Apollo. The muses will outsing her, and tear her flearing locks. I will go cite slug. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Gentle sir Gingle, the flower of my school, return my thanks to the honourable dame indulgence thy high deserving mother, for the glittering token the sent me. I shall deserve it in my readiness to accomplish thee. But where ended we yesterday?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: You were instructing me how to salute a lady, or so, if she had a monkey, or so, and wept, or so.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: This is but so, so.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: In case you find a lady weeping and mournful, for that her monkey is sick of the mumps, then say.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Fair ●ady weep not for your monkey.

sp.speaker: Comp
sp.p: This is bare and vulgar. Rather ●sh your salutation thus. 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 Claridiana.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: ●t as can be. T● is Claridiana was courted by the knight of the sun. My mother has ●ad that book to me. Sir your s●le is very h●h and lo●.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Ves sir, my master and I have gone over many ●s high a style, when we went to rob orchards for our dinners.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Twice double worthy dubbed madame —

sp.speaker: Giag.
sp.p: Twice double dubbed. What doth she wear a doublet do ladies ●e to wear doublets now?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You understand not. There was of late years a fashion, when haec vir, et hic mulier were in request. But gentle jingle, though thou dost stand under me, yet thou dost not understand me. Twice doubly because she hath two titles to her honour. The full a title of law which she hath from ●et ●u band who was dubbed knight with an unbloody sword. The second the second what ●est. him h●, the second. O I have it, because the is rich● in clothes then in jointure. But proceed we in your approach.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O so you have wonderfully enlightened enlighted me.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I have wipe ●and clarified the dull spectacle of thy intellect with the napkin of my comment.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Indeed now methinks spy her clearly without a lookingglass. But how should I forbid her to weep?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: To weep? Madam I forbid the ba●es between you and snow.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Ay, the knight's name sorrow?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Perhaps he's a o●y knight, (Like my master)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What imp. You are too nimble. Are you so saucy to step before me?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: (I was sane to step before him when we stole hens together, and he put me first into the hen-roost.)

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Truly captain methinks implement suggests very 〈◊〉 would willingly forbid those banes.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Forbidding banes? Away with this forbidding banes. It is a baneful ominous word, not befitting the wooing style. You shall mould all up in the fine pull passed of poetry thus.
Twice double worthy dubbed madam,
Whose virtues not the longest tongue can fathom.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I think ladies' garments are measured by th'ell and by the yard, but measuring their virtues by the fathom, I never heard of before.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Twice double worthy dubbed madam, whose long tongue no man can fathom.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O dismal. O dangerous! Take heed of stumbling so with your tongue when you speak of female tongues. Whose virtues not the longest tongue can fathom.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Whose virtues not the longest tongue can fathom.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Right and straight. Then on.
Souse not thy glittering globy eyne
In dreary teary salt sea brine.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Globy eyne? What's that?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Know'st thou not what globy is? I perceive than thou a● no traveller, thou hast not (As I have done) travelled about the globe of the earth. Know'st not what eyne be? I see thou art no poet, thou hast never read Chaucer. Hast thou never heard of eyne twain?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Souse not. This word will not down with me.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Mr. jingles queasy stomach cannot digest souse.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: The lady will think, I use to converse with tripe-wives, if I talk to her of souse.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Mr. you once courted a sousing dame, (A fulsome kitchen-wench.)

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Peace thou squeaking pig; or else the bandogs of these hands shall lug thy lagging ears. Souse not thy globy eyne. I tell thee this is not such as it is vulgarly taken. It is not a butcherly word, it is not descended from the tripe wife, nor hath it affinity with the frying-pan.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Nor did it ever hang cheek by jowl with a black pudding.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Mark the philosophy of the phrase. The roaring dashing element, the sea is salt, and brine is salt, and trickling tears are salted.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: And P. i. s. is salt.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.p: The sea, the brine, the tears, the tears, the brine, the sea. Why may they not all three thus dashing, soaking, sousing lie? It is a martial word. I use it often myself, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I too often when you tell me you'll give me a souse on the ear.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Souse not, etc. Fit. wondrous fit, as my presumed glove for my sweet-hand. It she wept for sorrow before, I shall now make her weep for joy to hear this eloquence.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: But my masters, you leave the poor monkey too long in distress. He'll die o'th mumps, unless we relieve him the sooner.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: 'Tis true. Pray go on. I am to say your monkey will recover. Master prompter do your part.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Then thus. Your sour legged, two-legged, man-imitating, two-handed, long-tailed play fellow, shall be readvanced to his pristine integrity of limbs.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: He had needs put in sound of wind and limb, for the Mumps lay siege to his throat, and breed more danger to his weasand, then to his ten bones.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Two-foot, four-foot? how can that be? Hath he six feet?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Six feet? six to one my master puts the trick of the louse upon him. I have known when he has blown them in a quill upon better men this this.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou art not worthy to be numbered among the two-footed, but rather art to be embased unto the fourfooted. If thou dost not understand how apes and monkeys are two-legged and two-handed; sometime they creep on all four. Imp. Show him how, sometime they stalk on tiptoe. Thus.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: If I had been an ape I should have climbed plum-trees bravely.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Let me see how you can imitate this.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Sometime they trace on all four thus.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Sometime they ride upon a mastiff dog thus. I want nothing now but my whip to keep this Lollard hound in awe.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Come off imp. Enough of this. We will send him hereafter for instruction to Paris garden, where he shall learn not only ape tricks, but the whipping of blind bears.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Paris garden? O fine Paris they say is a ●ne city in France. I am glad he will send me thither. No man can be a complete gentleman till he have learned their cringes and crinkling i'th hams: which is in excellent request to the heavens now adays.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Good sir, I hope myself, and such men of worth as I, have transported thence already plentiful loads of this French ware, that you shall save the labour and cost of living there at their dear ordinaries and precious dancing-schools, you must therefore in your stipend to me allow me, for that which I spent among counts, nobles, knights and monsieurs there; sometime it'h five pound ordinary, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: An horrible profitable lie my master never dined there but with o●llers and vintner's boys.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell you it cost me sour nobles to the usher of the dancing school to learn one trick, which they call le turn fuseau it wheels a man about, as a boy does a stone in a ho●pe, and makes him appear as round and uniform, as a joiner's turned bed post.

sp.speaker: Gins.
sp.p: I pray you learn me that whirligig trick.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You are not come to that. Be not so hasty, you are yet but in the rudiments, and to tell you plain, you must refund to me some charge for other proficiency before we aspire so high.
There was another vaulting trick called the ●ur.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: The base vulgar in English call it the hoister.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: It lifts a man up till he grow less and less like a hawk after a heron. Shaw. It cost me. Let me see.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: How much?

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Upon mine honour thirty crowns.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I think it was but twenty.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: By your leave master, I know better than you. Do not I keep your count book? I'm sure 'twas that week that you bought the jewellers rich diamond that was refused by so many nobles. They could not reach the price of it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O it was the late Queen mother's jewel. Thou didst still thou forgetful brat to leave it behind. I should have worn it at this public show. All Parnassus would have admired it.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Master, you lost the key of your cabinet. I durst not break it ope (The devil a jewel we have, but one that was bought of a pedlar, and in the country towns he makes a great show with it at bear. baitings, but in such civil places as this is, he durst not be seen with it.)

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I pray you when I am i'th humour of buying jewels, let me have the refusal of it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Thou shalt, because thou art an ingenious gentleman 〈◊〉 imp. Remember to set down a caveat in the margin of my inventory, that no man else ●y so much as look on it or have any price set of it.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Master Gingle I pray you pay me ten groars for entering this caveat in mine office. My fee my fee sir.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Come to me at my lodging , and I will lay ●alt on this birds ●yle dor fear of flying away.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell you master Gingle. It will go near to cost you the manner of Foolingham.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Let oaks and lands fly. I mean to glitter bright in diamond ▪ dear dight.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: You must add.
That men and dames may gaze, and say,
What star is that, that glides along this way?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: What starts is that, etc. oh excell● all the world could never have furnished me with such a tutor.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Say rather all the habitable circumference of this muddy massy earthy globe could not have afforded and suppeditated unto me so mellifluous an Indoctrinator, as is the curious captain compliment.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O that I could by metamorphosis be transformed into this eloquent man.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Thou hadst better be transformed with Apuleius into a golden ass.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I tell thee I have written a large book of instructions how a man should wear his clothes, on which side his purse should lie in his pocket, which stocking he should draw on first upon ominous days.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Indeed sir I have heard you often tell of a man that broke his leg because he pulled on his left stocking first on one of the dog days.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I sirrah, and there was another, that had the toothache seven years after, because he picked his teeth with the South end of his picktooth, in stead of the North, while he was in his chamber meditating a discourse to be offered up before a bevy of ladies.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Is there South and North a picktooth?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Ay, it was touched with a loadstone.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I would rather have picked my teeth with my knife thus, then have run into such a mischief.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What say you? what do you? do you wear a knife about you?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I'm sure it cost me a mark, and I got mine arms graven upon the blade, three hobby-horses or, prancing in a field ▪ or, bridled and saddled argent.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Then I must n●s tell you my mind. I hoped well that you would prove under my hands, but now I doubt you are no gentleman, I fear you'll never prove fashionable, I will rather employ my pains about other my scholars who have vowed never to wear knives.
What? wear a knife. Nay I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Nay, good sir, I pray you do not cast me off, I'll rather cast away this clownish tool.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I may take it up and wear it. No knife can wound my gentry.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: We burn day light. I must haste, and muster up my friends and advocates to plead for me in this court. Sirrah imp. Run to mistress Gingle, tell her, now 'tis time.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I will be your remembrancer to her: she shall protect you, else she is no mother for me.

sp.speaker: Geron with a fork on's neck.
sp.p: I have been mending my hedges, which the scurvy boy Ludio broke down. And now when I would rest at home, and take my nooning-nap, I must be vexed with my son, my wretched son. They say that Apollo keeps visitation today. I will lay my son at his palace gate, perhaps this feast day we may get some favour, some drop of his clemency. Exit.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Iv. goe rubbish what jug? bring away the looking glass. Thou dirty rubbish, thy singers have defiled the lace of my cuffs. Will not cuffing about the ears make you more cleanly?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: The lace is so thick, that I was fain to tug hard at it. I know not what can foul it, unless the smoothing-iron cast a rusty colour through the paper

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Out upon thee for an old rusty liar. The glass ▪ hold it on the other side. You know I do not love to behold that mole on this cheek. Thou spiteful baggage, more yet on the left hand. Is that the left hand?

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.p: Here's my left hand.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p:
Ay, but the other side is my left hand. You must conform
your eyes and hands to your ▪ mistress, and forget which is your own right or left. Does my veil hang in true proportion?

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.p: I can say nothing for any portion, but in hangs just behind you.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Unless I be set all in print, the poetical muse will make times on me, when they see me in a● judgement hall. But jug, what had my son to breakfast this morning?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.p: A pullet's wing.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: That's not forsooth. What nothing else?

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.p: Forsooth a piece of pie too but so sooth mistress, if you give me leave, I'll tell you what they say of him.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: What? who? Why?

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.p: Marry forsooth Philoponus, and others eke also do say, if you feed him so much, that he will never prove: a scholar.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: Prove scholar? Do they think my child is so low born as to be made a ●y scholar? Shall such a keen refined wit be dulled and embased, by plodding on a book? What is Philoponus but a bookworm, an inkhorn squirt, a botching patcher of Latin shreds what is this learning, but a little gibberish in the tongue, a sheepish look in the face, and penniless famine in the purse? I he more scholar a young man is, the less like to speed of a rich wife. I will have my son the mark and wish of the most renowned dames.

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.p: I do not so hate scholars, but that I could ●ne in my heart to ma●y Philoponus at a venture.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p:
I will, as mannerly as I may, tell Apollo that it is an honour to his school, that such a one as my son was of it, though but for a taste of the muse's dish, a
gentle touch of the verge of their garment. Ay, but is my coach ready?

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.p: One of the horses is very unruly, the coachman. talks like a rogue, and says that nothing but a wise will tame him.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: This lewd horse-rubber's tongue must be tamed I doubt he is three quarters drunk.

sp.speaker: Jug.
sp.p: That's no news.

sp.speaker: Indulgence
sp.p: I must away, the hour runs with swifter race than my horses. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus quartus. Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Geron and Retro his son.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Keep on thy way, dost thou not see? hold on that path. Seest thou not how my staff doth wise thee the way? I think thou cam'st backward into the world, that now art damned to this crablike pace. Shall I never be rid of this office? So: stand still now methinks I see the porch of great Apollo's temple. O great Apollo, if my son have thus deserved to be punished, yet what hath guiltless Geron, what hath he offended?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: O. terg. ollota nodrap. Su.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Thou dost well to humble thyself before great Apollo. But why to pardon us? Why me?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Rethaf, o. Rethaf.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What sayest thou to thy father?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Ti. saw. rvoy. tlaf.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What sayest thou? Was it my fault?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Voy. taes. 'em. ta. ot. ih, a koob.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Did I set you at too high a book? You were too proud of your wit, and would needs slide over the rudiments, and leap at first into an higher form, than your capacity would reach unto.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Im rehtom. Im. rethom.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Thy mother, thy mother. Ay, it is true, thy mother would needs have it so. I must needs say 'twas her fault, not mine. She ever jogged me, and told me, that her Rowland was as good a scholar, as his master, and that the 〈◊〉 est book did best befit his ●gh flown 〈◊〉 and now alas thy long long punishment penance unto me, then to thy two years have I been 〈◊〉 at home. It grieves and grates me ears to hear this backward language imposed by Apollo's doom on my wretched child. It wounds mine eyes to see these backward steps. And yet remains a furtiuer time for me,
sp.l: To be the scorn and by word of this place.
Old Geron's overforward child
Retorted for his hastiness,
Is made the prou● 〈◊〉 of these times.
And likened to soon ●ipe soon rotten fruit ▪
But how long time remains yet unexpired
〈◊〉 this unnatural preposterous task?
〈◊〉 ●o. Rey. Sa●. Norey.
〈◊〉 I, so, it is one whole livelong year.
●ich thy poor father (Spent with tears and grief)
Scarce hopes now to outlast. Alas
The candle of my days is almost spent,
It waveth in the snuft, and little oil
Is left to make it flame.
And yet alas too soon these blasts of sighs
Will puff it out ▪ ●ese tears will drown it quite.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Rethaf. reed. Rethaf.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What sayest thou my dear son, too dear to me, that hast me cost so deep a punishment.

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Tell. su. geb so. ol● pa.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Well what shall we beg of Apollo?

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Ot, nodrap. su. sibt. ●ey.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: To pardon this year to us, and release thee? I fear thy wishes are far larger than our hopes.

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Irrem. ollopa.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Merry Apollo? I doubt his ears are stopped, and I have heard the gods u●e not to recall their dooms, which they have once pronounced.

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Keeps. o● svesu●n.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: What? wouldst thou have me speak to Musaeus Apollo's priest, to intercede for thee for this remission?

sp.speaker: Ret.
sp.p: Os ot. mih.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l: In good time here he comes forth.
But son I dare not approach to him.
O what a trembling reverence doth possess
My limbs, and all benumbs my chill cold blood,
When I behold his awful gravity.
Let us retire beside this shady tree
This mossy bank will rest my weary limbs,
And give me time to recollect my spirits.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Grave guide of tender youth, interpreter
Of great Apollo's laws chief secretary
Unto the learned muses, all your words
are lodged safe in this laborious breast.
Think your command's no sooner said than done ▪

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.l: Careful Philoponus, I approve your pains
And have already recommended you
Unto Apollo's self. O that the rest
Of those, that undertake this worthy task,
Pretending to the liberal sciences,
Could so acquit themselves.
But 〈◊〉 all seeing 〈◊〉 in circling round
About both hemispheres of this large world,
Hath spied that some (Oh too too great a sum)
Have s●ly crept within the verge and pa●
Of his dominions. In truth they strangers are,
Nay enemies and rebels to his laws;
Yet would be counted natives of his school,
By them his tender plants corrupted are,
Distorted, bruised, hindered of their growth.
Think they that these foundations have been l●
These cells erected, and those temples dight
To harbour such foul el●es? Shall snorting sloth
Think here to nestle, fixed to his bed,
As is the slow-paced snail unto his shell?
Shall wanton pleasure think to revel here?
Shall toying apish p●ating compliment
Outface the muses, tear Apollo's locks,
Entice away the tender brood, with shows
Of empty words, and bubbles vanishing?
Shall shifting sharks defraud their innocence?
Shall hasty heady novices outleap their master's lo●,
Presuming on their wit, and undertake
To read a lecture to their teacher? No.
'Tis well that some have heretofore for this
Been made examples of such hastiness.
Nay let them backward go, that thus have run.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.l: Alas poor child, I see, he meaneth thee.
Have pity on us great Apollo's priest.
Worthy Philoponus entreat Mus●us for my child.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Does your child desire so much?

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: D●g. ris keeps. ros. 'em.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Speak for him good sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: His language is so harsh, that I will speak, if it be but to rid my ears of this preposterous sound. Venerable Mus●us. May it please our lord Apollo, now after two years penance to remit the remaining year.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: If there be evidence that in this time, he hath retired and plied what formerly he overslipped in his rudiments.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Myself can partly witness that.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: It may be that Apollo will consider him. But let us haste up to Parnassus' top. The time is come, the court must now begin.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: My heart is warm with hope to follow them.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Still I say and swear upon my virtues, that you are mistaken. Have you been so long my scholar, and are you yet unacquainted with the calendar of my stipend book?

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: My bargain was to allow you five crowns a month, and will you now wire-draw me to thirteen months i'th year? When I was Apollo's scholar, I'm sure Musaeus reckoned but quarterly, 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 but twelve months i'th year.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Apollo's priest must follow his masters walk, the suns yearly passage through the twelve signs of the zodiac. I will have nothing to do with astronomy.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Ay, but our almanacs every year reckon but twelve months.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: What dost thou tell me of almanacs? Usurers go by the almanac. I scorn that griping trade. My month is four weeks ●ust, you may remember them by the changing your shirts, every fourth shirt determines my pay.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I reckon the month by one shirt.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Who shall be judge between us?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Judge between us? Am not I thine instructor ▪ I'll be thy judge. For every one of my months I teach thee a several strain of courtesy and so thou hast of me in the year, documents accordingly, thirteen to the dozen.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: My master's father was a baker, and therefore he allows an odd call of courtesy, neatly chipped.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Si●a imp. Draw out the catalogue and number them.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: The first month, the semicircle.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Ay, with my hat thus. To make just half a circumference.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Remember always the drop withal.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: In my motion, my gold hatband must fall down, thus.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I cry fallings: this is my fee, I trow.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: It is an excellent emblem, and signifies that for love of your friend, you will cast away your gold, and trample it under your feet, and that's the reason that gentlemen now adays wear their hatbands loose. Register proceed.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: The second month the calf-clasp.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Perform it with imp. That I may view you the better. Do you remember that in arching your arm over his shoulder, you must never touch his band or garment behind, but apprehend the calf with your first touch entirely.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I warrant you, I am old dog at that.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: If I had known you had been an old dog, I would not have trusted you with my calf. Ba.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: And before I dismiss the calf, I give it the gentle nip or prasye thus.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Ba, ba. No butcher nips a calf more neatly in the rump.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Which shows your fervency of love, that you are loath to be unclasped from your friend's intimity.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I have it to a hai●e.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Register walk on your monthly pace.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: The third month, the gentle shrug.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: I must tell you, you have not got that perfect yet.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Not my shrug sir? That was my last lesson.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Indeed sir I was by, when signior Gosso in that action smiled, and asked if you were not lousy.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: O there's your fault, gentle jingle. A hundred to one you shrugged but with one shoulder.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I would advise you hereafter to shrug by a lookingglass, that you may see after what manner you do it.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Indeed my lookingglass is broken with dancing with it in my hand, to mark the postures of my face when I capered. But I'll buy another.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay, you must buy two, that one may reflect upon the other, and then may you at once see your motion in your shrug both before and behind.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p:
O excellent! for this double glass, I'll give you
a double fee. But, I pray you sir, wherein is my shrug faulty?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: My dear scholar, thou must know, there are divers kinds of shrugs, there is the miser's shrug, and that is accompanied with the scratching of the elbow: there is the beggar's shrug, and that's done with a quick motion, snatching, to make a six ▪ footed bandog leave his hold.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: My master and I act that at home sometimes, when we are loath to part with an old friend, our linen.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: There is a winter shrug, and that's performed with the hands ensconced in a must, and a fox-furred co● close gi●t. There is a drowsy shrug, and that sometime befalls a gallant, when he has set up all night at cards, and saved the pulling off his boots. This shrug is commonly performed with displaying out the arms, and yawning with the mouth, which represents a kind of leopard's face. And lastly, there is a gentle Italian shrug.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: I pray you sir let me go with you let me see. The miser's shrug, the winter shrug, the drowsy shrug, the lousy shrug. I shall hardly carry away all these.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Nay, you must carry away none of these. You must leave them all behind you. The last and only gentle shrug, is your Italian shrug.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O the Italian shrug. There 'tis. How's that? I shrug with desire to learn it.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p:
That shrug is performed by lifting up both shoulders exactly together with one uniform motion, somewhat swift, and holding them a while in suspense, with the neck somewhat couching, and the chin thrust out, than the shoulders are to be let down again, as it were by a double pulley, with a
slow motion, which by degrees vanisheth. And if you will accomplish it with a grace, you must all the while cast your eyes into a leering posture.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: O excellent school of virtue! But when must I use this shrug?

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Upon divers occurring cases, very usefully. But especially when you are asked a question, which you cannot deny with safety, nor assent unto with honour. In such a two-forked dilemma, the shrug relieves you, and you come off with reputation of wisdom.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: This is an oracle to me, I pray you expound by example.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: Put case that some fair and honourable lady were mentioned at the table, and thereupon some busy curious gentleman should ask you whether there passed no terms of love between you and her. To deny it, were a derogation from your honour. To love or be beloved is honourable. For you to acknowledge it, were perhaps dangerous. Some of the company may be your rival, and so rusty iron may leap out of the eel-skin, and prick your skin. Thus Venus may be exchanged for Mars. And of the two, he's the most dangerous companion to a man's naked side. One shrug quits all this, by which you seem to say, I am not to be examined upon this interrogatory. I stand upon my guard, all armed in silent wisdom.

sp.speaker: Ging.
sp.p: Incomparable dogments. Mus●us never taught me so good a lesson.

sp.speaker: Comp.
sp.p: But high time it is for us to appear, the session is begun by this. The villain Praco is like death, and will spare none. Methinks I heare him cry, captain compliment appear. Go coach it up with your mother. I and my

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Will march up the hill on foot. Here sir, I appear sir.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Here sir, at hand. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: See how thy soul was snared with sophistry.
No author here alleged for Hedone,
But quells those poisons with their antidotes.
Mark Tully in that place doth smoothly plead
For youthful Calius, so to palliate
His clients true objected vanities.
There Tully played the lawyer for his fee.
Behold him now a sage philosopher:
Discoursing of old age, he there concludes,
In voluptatis regno virtutem non posse consistere,
That virtue cannot stand where pleasure reigns.
Anacreon was a wanton epicure,
A glozing poet, but lewd moralist:
He should his soul to Venus and her son,
Such writers we for style, not matter read.
Siren from Terence pleads, that in young men
Deep quaffing, roating, whoring, is no fault.
Doth not that poet represent the parts,
The passions, and several enormities
Of cockering doting fathers, of lewd sons,
Of cheating slaves, and cogging parasites?
Thus he describes the vices of those times,
That readers might them hate, not imitate.
S●, comic poets set out drunkenness
In him that pleads for Bacchus, and the while
Doth swagger, stagger, swallow, wallow, snort,
The soul ▪ that this picture is, the more
That swinish vice breeds loathing of itself.
If I would on a comic stage display
Virtue in conflict stoutly labouring,
And then in conquest honoured by fame;
First would I personate her enemy
In some such busy guiles and forgery,
As this lewd Siren represents to thee.
The rest of authors, motives, arguments,
Which in that letter you so stood upon,
Are of no better stamp, as I have shown.
And can fa●re more at large.
But why should I distrust thy judgement so?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: You have, judicious Philoponus,
More hardly in the grove, more briefly here,
Dispelled those mists, which that enchanting witch
Had cast before mine eyes. I see, I see
The light of reason, then eclipsed quite,
But now reviving my recovered sight.
O how I loathe, and hate that juggling hand,
That wrote, or teached to me these baleful lines.
What sacrifice to virtue can I yield
More ●r, than thus to tear that robe, wherein
That poison was conveyed, to be to me
As was the deadly shirt to Hercules?
So would I also her.
sp.stage: He tears thee letter, and stamps on it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Your best revenge on her will be henceforth,
no more to speak with her by word or pen, women's fair words work deep with passive men

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: What heaps of thanks owe I, and cannot pay, to such a faithful other self, whose hand hath reached forth that Ariadne's thread which me out of this labyrinth hath led.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Come let us up into Apollo's court. The session is long since begun. There shall you more confirm your resolution, by hearing Apollo himself in his judgement seat. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I tell thee again, I have no great hope of it. You have suffered so many repulses, that if I were in your case — where is he. So ho. Come along, mend your pace. What? have you the gout?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Alas in foot, and hand too. My father and grandsire had so.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Stand up for shame. Else how will you appear in Apollo's presence, so much as to present your request.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Well. I'll stretch my limbs so far, though I be already tired with our long journey.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: A long journey from your cottage to Apollo's court? when your tent is fixed but on the other side of the wall. A man may fling a horse lose so far.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p:
I'll rather be fed with horse bread, than travail so far again to fetch whitebread. But I
pray you let us sit down. I shall talk much wiser, sitting then standing.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Do not judge's sit● as now Apollo does there. And I hope they are wiser, than those that stand to hear them.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I judge standing, that thou hast little understanding that art such an enemy to standing.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: But sir Drudo, why do you discourage me from hope of admittance?

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: The truth is, I see no great reason why you should be admitted. I'm sure for these seven years, every visitation day you have been shut out of doors by Musaeus as soon as ever he espied you lying upon the bench in Apollo's court. And for the most part, when your name hath been called aloud by Praco, you have been asleep, and were fain to be jogged and shaked again before you would answer.
Out upon thee, what art thou in a lethargy? I think thy mother was asleep when thou wast begotten. So bo. So bo. I tell thee again, after seven repulses, why shouldst thou knock at Apollo's gate.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I dare not knock at this gate ▪ the hammer that hangs on it, is so cold and heavy. And why should I disquiet the muses with such a noise? Perhaps some of them are asleep in Apollo's lap.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Thou dormouse, thou iv'st in a perpetual winter: think'st thou them like to thee?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I cannot climb this hill. I pray fetch Apollo hither. Or be you Apollo.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What shall Drudo be so bold. No. But say what thou canst. Apollo sees and hears all things in all places.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Why then Apollo. Drudo, I crave admittance.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What is your claim?

sp.speaker: Slug
sp.p: I am the top of my kin. I am Slim slug, sluggy Sluggorum.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What's that to your plea? Are you a kin to the Muses.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I have long prescription time out of time. I have been entertained evermore by some of Apollo's prentices. They have kept me and said me in their chambers, and huged me in their bed. I never wanted among them, those that would rather rest with me in a cold morning, then dance after the muse's pipe with benumbed hands and chattering teeth.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: All wines have some lees,
All beehives some drones.
Thinkest thou that such prescription shall get thee admittance?

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I am weary of sitting. I think it were better for me to lie down upon this bank. I shall talk much wiser yet when my head lies lower than my heels, for then all my spirits and wits sink down into my brain. So I'll tell thee now what learned counsel I gave to a young scholar, when he told me that his master chid him for keeping his bed. Why (Quoth I to him) then answer your master, I pray you sin, would you have me ●ll my bed? your law, that you give us, is, nil dabis, aut vendes. —

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Very learnedly applied to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: When I read lecture to my auditors. —

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Surely then thou givest a deep nod at every s● point.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: I enjoin them, sell your books, sell your inkhorns, sell your candlesticks, sell your points, but never sell your beds. The bed is the seat and throne of a scholar. For contemplation requires quietness. And when is a man more quiet, then when he is in 〈◊〉 bed? Ergo.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Spoken like a philosopher, but of the epicures sect.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Nay you shall have philosophy up to the elbows. The bed is the beginning and end of a man. When we come into the world, are not our mother's said to be brought to bed? When we die, are not we on our death bed? Whilst we live, when are we more innocent then when we are asleep in our bed? than we think nobody any hurt. When are mischiefs done by men, but when they are awake, and employ themselves most busily? Ergo.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: It seems so by thee, for thou art seldom awake thus long, but to do some such mischief at to talk in this manner.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: The best philosophers have said, and I have heard it in Apollo's school. Motus fit propter quietem. Nature intends motion, that it may attain rest. And all scholars know, that what is desired, as the end, is better than that, which is ordained as the means to it.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Nay siria, the best of them say, that motion is better than rest. For the heavens move continually, and the earth, which is the dregs of the world, that rests, and slugs like thee. The day is for labour, and the night for rest. And I hope the day is far better than the night. Ergo.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Well. I have all the earth on my side: I'm safe enough. Go you and dance after the stars. I'll hold my rest here.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Enough of this philosophy. Thou lolling lubber, lazy bough, get up, rise old hunks, rise drunken bear, or I'll go in without thee.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: A bear? no. I'm a worthier beast, by my hardly rising. I am like an elephant.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: I wood thou hadst a castle upon thy back, than I wood hang thee out for a sign, and it should be called the drowsy inn. Come away, your name it called ere this at the session, and Praco won't savour you. You will be in, forty marks in issues.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: My turn is always last. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: S●spbu. Scopas. Come away with the cushions. Lay that carpet smoother. When were these cushions brushed. Sirrah. ha?

sp.speaker: Scop.
sp.p: I have heard say, that too much brushing will we are them out.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Thou lozel. Hath slug infected you? Why do you give such kind entertainment to that cobweb?

sp.speaker: Scop.
sp.p: It shall have Tom drums entertainment. A flap with a fox tail.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p:
For the preparing this judgement seat. I pronounce judgement of banishment against all presumptuous cobwebs. The court will rise, and
come upon us ere we are aware. Scopas go see how forward they are, and bring away the frankincense.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Where are they, that say that Ludio is the canker of the school? I have pronounced a knocking apology before Apollo and all his court.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: What, nimble Ludio, is the session so far on?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Unto thee, oh Thuriger, I am the nuntio, to tell thee, that Apollo and his actors are by this time come to actus quintus, scaena quarta Praco told me they will all come down hither to act scena ultima.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I shall be ready for them. But I pr●, Ludio, how did mistress Gingle behave herself?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: She never ceased crying out to Apollo, oh the generous captain compliment! O that he may bold ●is tenement. Apollo himself was fain to command her silence.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Did not Siren creep into the souls of the auditory?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: My friend Siren slid on smoothly, like my feet upon the ice. I think she has unbent Apollo's bow. She will have a good day of it, I hope. Young jingle in his trial stood much upon his gentry, and carried himself like a fine dancing courtier. When I heard slug called, I thought we should tarry long, and so away came peel-garlic Ludio, to get him a room before hand here.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: But thou tellest me nothing all this while of thy own trial. Were you not put to it shrewdly?

sp.speaker: Ludio
sp.p: I trow I put Apollo and all his muses to it. There can no sentence pass against me. My defence was so strong and unanswerable.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I am sorry that my office called me away from hearing you, will you do me the honour to impart to me some of your discourse?

sp.speaker: Lud.
sp.p: I have it here engrossed and recorded.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I wonder how you could borrow so much time from play, as to compose so large a declaration?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I have a ●end in a corner, I teach him the knacks of gaining, how to cut a bum card, how to help a die, and such like, and he in kind requital has drawn an apology for me in form of law, according to the style or Apollo's court.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Could you before all them pronounce it lustily, as if it had been your own making?

sp.speaker: Ludio
sp.p: I have a certain virtue called audacity. I hat did bear me our where my wit or memory failed.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I ●ng to hear some of it. Can you say it?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: So, ●o: as we do our lessons, with a casting a leer eye sometime upon my paper.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: It is l●ge. I will n● 〈◊〉 ●le thee to say it over. Only read I pray you some of the principal points.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I tell thee here be above a dozen of points. You shall have a touch of the fore-point thus.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I have known the time when you have had neither fore not ●d point, when you have returned from spurn point.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p:
First, I looked gravely like Cato, and withal, cheerfully like pu●rilis and then to show what confidence I had in my cause, I stroked up my foretop with the comb of my finders thus. My sister had
sprinkled it with rose water, and my lips too, to make my rhetoric the sweeter.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: No doubt rose water added a sweet sound to your words.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Then I made obeisance thrice, with a nimble low stoop which I learned when we played at duck friar. Then I criyed ●m, ●em to clear my voice, and to provoke the auditory to answer me with their gentle expectation.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Here is a large entry to a low house.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Then displaying my naked protesting hands, I said. O thou lovely lord of learning, beauteous, bounteous Apollo.
sp.l: O thou ever moving Phoebus,
Whose golden locks and silver bow,
Embellish heaven and earth below.
O ye assistant sister's ●ne,
Attend this just defence of mine.
sp.p: What law, what justice, what reason can pronounce a 'gainst Ludio the sentence of expulsion? Is not Apollo's school styled ladus literarius. Is it not Sc●ola from 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 otium, remedy, play, relaxation? What talk we of Apollo's court. The whole world is made free of ludios trade, and dances after his pipe.

What is our life but a game, wherein some win, some lose, some idly look on, some have good fortune, and will not be known of their winnings, others have bad luck, and curse their stars and fates; some cheat and ●ke, and others are befooled?
All dame nature's lump is a true Ludio. If you banish Ludio, you must banish the heavens and elements.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: What? is this brat become a philosopher?

sp.speaker: Ludis.
sp.p:
The highest fixed stars, what do they all the year but dance their measures, and keep there
their stately distances, and, to show their mirth and wantonness, they with their glaring eyes twinkle on their spectators. The planets have variety of dances, sometime grave pavins, otherwhile ●mble galliards.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: ●e Sellinger's round.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Now a pace forward, now retiring backward.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Like a new coranto.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: What sayest thou Thuriger? did not I play the astronomer well?

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Better then sixteen almanac-makers, with all their sextile aspects, and fiery triplicities.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: But now sir here was I put to my trumps, when I came to bring in our lord Phoebus himself for an example, in my own defence, in his own presence. Therefore I begun with craving pardon. O majestic lord of the day, moderator of the year, ring-leader of all the glittering lamps; give poor Ludio leave to show that in the work of thy bright regiment, thou canst not be without him. Dost thou not all the year long recreate thyself by taking the air about the hill of heaven in thy guilded caroche, drawn with four prancing horses?

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Some mortals now adays have in their coach more horses than don ▪ Phoebus.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: In this thy yearly journey thou art so frolic every spring, that thou givest our mother earth a green ●owne.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.l: That is (Our virgins say)
A pretty kind of play.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: And in thy journal circle when thou comest and goest, every day and night, methinks thou playest at no ▪ peep, and hide and seek.
sp.l: All night it our all hid. But in the day
we seek about. For what, say I, but play?

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: O impudence! How durst thou base flea, skip thus high into Apollo's face. Didst thou not fear to be pierced through with the least dart of his beams?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: The truth is, one of Apollo's learned council had like to pulled me down, when he told me that it was against law to produce the judge for a witness. Else I had gone on to allege his playing at quoits with Cyparissus.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: He would have conned you small thank for that. But, how did our lord Apollo look upon you all this while?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: methought he put his hand towards his quiver, and withal, shaked his golden locks. Then thought I, 'twas time for me to glide down lower, and talk of lady Luna. Mistress moon (Quoth I) what is her monthly task, but to run a gossipping throughout all the twelve signs in the high street of the zodiac?.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: The sign of the ram, the bull: the lion, and the rest, they are taverns set up by Bacchus, for the gods to feast in. Are they not?.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: She knocks at every door, and tarries two days at the least in each of those houses. And as the sun courts her, she makes curtsies in her round walk, sometimes bashfully putting on her mask.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: That is in conjunction.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Otherwhile she shows her half face very demurely.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Half moon; like my cheese.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: And after that appears her broad owls face, to allure Endymion to be in love with her.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: The shepherd with the bush of thorns has prevented sleepy Endymion, and gotten up thite before him.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: The waves in the sea, what do they, but play at truss and leapfrog on one another's back? The winds in the air perform one perpetual exercise, and that is blowpoint.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Sometimes they blowest the points of steeples, and this is a very high point, worth consideration.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: They play very merrily: and therefore we often hear them ●g and whis●le.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Leave of now your rehearsal Ludio. Why prated you of the stars and winde●? What's this to you, and to those creatures that have bound themselves to the school trade? Do the mules play?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Yes undoubtedly, the nine muses play at nineholes: every muse hath her hole

sp.speaker: T●r
sp.p: Yes, and every hate hath her muse. But what then becomes o● the ten h●e?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: That's a great one for Apollo their master and ours.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Thinkst thou, that Apollo will be moved with these reasons, to let such a vermin harbour in the pigeon house of the mr.?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Do you think that I will suck their eggs? Do I look like a su● 〈◊〉? I am sure the auditory did entertain thy speech with the sign of approbation ▪ hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: That was 〈◊〉 but the yonger sort, and those that stood at the lower end of the session hall.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: I am much 〈◊〉 taken if Apollo himself did not in the end hum and 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I think rather Apollo frowned on you.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I think rather that Mercury frowned on me.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: Why Mercury? he is not there.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p:
I'll tell thee, honest Thuriger, whilst I was in
the hair of my pleading, some villain, born under the planet Mercury, nims away my satchel that lay behind me.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: What loss suffered you in that vessel?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: The shipwreck of all my best householdstuff, and tools of my trade. What think you, Thuriger, does this forebode ill luck to me?.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: I think it had been better luck, if you had been robbed of those commodities seven years ago. But see yonder comes my Scopas.

sp.speaker: Scopas.
sp.p: They are coming hard by. Here is the frankincense. Put it in yourself.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.p: This fire is almost out, stir it up.

sp.speaker: Scopas.
sp.p: Laurel wood doth soon spend.

sp.speaker: Thur.
sp.l: Apollo's judgement seat
Makes all things pure and neat. Apollo's judgement, etc.

div.head: Actus quintus. Scaena sex● et ultima.
div.stage: Thuriger. Scopas. Drudo. Lauriger. Praco. Musaeus. Clio. Euterpe. Philoponus. Amphibius. Siren. Ludio ▪ implement. Slug. Geron. Retro. N●ce.

sp.speaker: Lauriger.
sp.p: Come along, come on in rank.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: On afore, on afore ▪ hold up the book. Give room, room, more room.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: We must have room, more than the whole city of Rome.
Clio, you must sit down, and you Euterpe. Musaeus craves your assistance.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: P●o do your office.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: Silentium: et tacete. Our lord Apollo by his deputed judge, the venerable Musaeus, doth command silence, and chargeth all, whom it may concern, to attend the court, and hear the charge

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.l: Our great Apollo's palace seemeth like
A spacious garden set with choicest flowers,
Wherein creep up by small unlean degrees
Unuseful, hurtful, and unsavoury weeds;
Which overgrow and choke the better plants,
And make the tender flowers to hang the head.
Himself chief gardener hath, from yonder top
Of this our sacred ●ll, even now overviewed
All that his herbage, and with cautious eye
Discerned and designed by his doom,
What must be cherished, and what weeded out.
Me, his unworthy servant, he appoints,
As under-gardner, with that wholesome hook.
To check, or nip, or toot up what he damned.
〈◊〉 by oracle he did unfold,
What lot attends on every name enrolled.
Praco, read the record, and cite the names.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Memorandum. On Apollo's shrove-day, being the eight and twentieth of Aquarius, in the great hall of the western top of Parnassus. Our sovereign lord Apollo sitting in person upon oyer and terminer, after full hearing of all parties, did then and there adjourn the court, to be presently continued at the foot of the said h●, under the laurel, at the temple gate, and to be there consummate by his reverend judge Musaeus.
Nomina reorum.
The names of the parties sentenced by Apollo.
Siren, the first is Siren. Appear Siren spinster.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: She spins nothing but spider's webs, to catch flies.

sp.speaker: Laur
sp.p: Siren come out what do you lurk? Appear in your likeness, and hear your doom.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Vous havez Si●.

sp.speaker: Siren.
sp.p: I have a great deal more to say for myself, and for my lady Hedone. I hope, I shall be heard.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: You would fain be heard; because you think your tongue enchants. There is no pleading now. Apollo's doom is past.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: You must hear the judge, or else be pressed to death presently.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Siren, then thus for Siren.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Record the sentence Praeco.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: My pen is as nimble as your tongue.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Siren must first be searched.

sp.speaker: S●.
sp.p: Sacred dispenser of Apollo's justice, I hope you will not suffer a poor nymph to be used so immodestly. If I must be ransacked, I p●y you let it be done by a jury of muses. The three graces, empaneled with them, will make up the whole number of twelve good women, and true.

sp.speaker: C●o.
sp.l: If I be made fore-woman of your jury,
You shall be doomed by justice, not by fury.

sp.speaker: Irpe.
sp.l: We Mus● envy no man,
Much less will wrong a woman.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: We shall not need to trouble you noble Clio ▪ nor you sweet Euterpe. This search is only of her upper garment. I auriger lift up her vail.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Come, I must love, and court thee now.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: O ugly a filthy fi●es tail.

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: Pull off her head of yellow locks.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: Oh black bristles. O nasty vermin!

sp.speaker: Musaeus.
sp.p: This seeming glozing nymph is nothing else, but an ugly sea ▪ monster. She is damned to return to the sea, and there to be tossed, and doused, together with Scylla, that monstrous shame of nature. But, before you ●icke her out, let her take a message to carry to dame Hedone, if ere they meet again. That is, that Hedone shall ever unseparably be manacled to lupe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O just doom, that pleasure shall be always fettered to pain. Which also this false Siren proves. ●irst, a face seeming fair to meet with: but if you further go, turpem desinit in piscem Mulus formosa superne.

sp.speaker: Laur. drudo. Praco. Philop omnes.
sp.p: Out with her.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I will have one kick more at her for inveigling me: out bitch. — exit Siren.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: On Praco. Who is next?

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: The next is Ludio. Appear Ludio gamester. Vous bavez Ludio.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Here appears poor bankrupt Ludio. I have suffered losses by misfortune.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What misfortune? fire? or thieves?

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: Ay sir. Thieves, they have robbed me of all my brass coin, and unbound paper books. I must set up with a new stock.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The rogue means his cards and counters.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p:
Thou bold else, that canst not at thy trial for
get thy play. Apollo fits thee with a doom, that thou shalt play uncessantly.

sp.speaker: Ludio
sp.p: I'm glad of that a perpetual playday.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: And thou shalt ●ue fifty playfellows.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: So much good company do the better.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: They are the fifty daughters of Danaus; whose play is still to fetch and fetch water in a sieve. Thou must play still at dice.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: At dice? that's well ▪ I'll cheat all those fifty wenches.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: But thus. Thy dice thou must put into a bottomless box. So, when thou throwest, they fall to the ground: and thou must take them up: they fall again, thou stoopest again. Thi● is the m●ll bothering, wherein thou must run ●und eternally.

sp.speaker: ●il
sp.p: He that would find Lu●, must seek him at the sign of the labour in va●e.

sp.speaker: Ludio.
sp.p: O would I had studied when I played ▪ rather than thus to play at lost labour eternally. Exit.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Mistress indulgence 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Blind fortune hath quit her of that; but she is true to her name indulgence.

sp.speaker: Praeco.
sp.p: Mistress indulgence Gingle. Spinster.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: All the wool and flax, t●at ever she spun, I will eat and fear no choking.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: Doth she not appear?

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: She scoured awa● in her coach with her son, and said she would dwell no longer in Thessaly, i● her sons best instructor be not suffered here. And as she fled, her coach overturned.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: Let her four wheels carry Apollo's curse with her, that none of her kindred shall ever get above the petty form of Apollo's school. Pass o● Praco.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Jo●n Gingle, gentleman would-be.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Apollo pronounceth that his lot must be, before he be forty years old, to spend all his five manors upon the five senses: except the mansion house of Foolingham, which is entailed to the heirs of his body woefully begotten.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: For my part I will not be of counsel to cut off the entail.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Compliment, pretended captain, alias captain Comp. Fashionmonger.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: He is ●led, ●s cheer.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Fled with a witness. For he flew like a bird up in the air.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Then has he saved us a labour. For Apollo had doomed him to be blown up with Vulcan's bellows into the middle region of the air.

sp.speaker: L●r.
sp.p: The boys in the outer-court of Apollo's palace, when they perceived by mistress jingles discontent, that the captain was like to be banished, they prevented execution, by tying squibs to his skirts; which being fired, this light fusball mounted up into the ay● as high as a ●arke.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: One boy said, that this was the captain's lofty capering trick.

sp.speaker: Drudo.
sp.p: And whither did this whirl wind carry him?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Who knows? But most do think to the island of Coxcombria, a place thick impeopled with such riff-raff.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Jack implement, page to the aforesaid compliment. Vous havez implement.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: Here sir, at hand. I pray you master Musaeus be good to a poor page. I had but a hard service under him my bed and board was scarce to the maintenance of a water-spaniel. I would sane go to school again.

sp.speaker: Mufaus.
sp.p: How right this boy meets with Apollo's doom thy lot is for the school again: but there for one whole year thou must smooth out the dog's care● of all thy fellow's books; and vow to ply thy book as nimbly as ever thou didst thy Maste● apery, or the haughty vaulting horse.

sp.speaker: Implement
sp.p: I vow, and will. Else let me ●ide our blind horse that kicks us on the back.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: What slug, could you not come along with us? You must be lag. An hour will scarce serve you, though your journey be short, and down the hill.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Soft fire, sweet malt

sp.speaker: Musaeus
sp.p: The next name Praco.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Slim slugge.

sp.speaker: Drud.
sp.p: Answer to your name.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Hum. ha ▪

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He will not answer, unless you give him all his titles. Sluggus Sluggorum. Sl●e of Slug-hall.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Why then Slim slug, Sluggum Sluggorum, Slug of slug-hall, sleeper.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Vous havez slug. Stand forth and attend the sentence.

sp.speaker: Mus●us.
sp.p: Thou night-bird, in whose nasty nest all books and inkhorns, and all things else are moldy, but thy bed. Yet there dost thou pig in, and pig out, without molesting the feathers by concussion.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Stand upright, and leave thy yawning.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Thou that never mayest infect the muse's habitation, Apollo doth banish thee into Lubberland.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: Lubberland? I'm glad of that. I shall earn my fourteen pence a day there by snorting. But who shall carry me thither?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay, you must foot it thither, there lies the marrow of your punishment.

sp.speaker: Slug.
sp.p: O that I had Tom cortats everlasting shoes! But ho which is the way to Lubberland? Has none of you been there will you go with me? will you in the freeze coat? It is a fine country. There are rivers of muskadine , and bridges of brawn, parks of Ven● ▪ son pasties, paled about with puddings and sausages. H●y for our town, heigh for Lubberland.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Praco, I think thou dreamest of Lubberland. Why do not you pass on?
Yong novice, apprentice.

sp.speaker: Novice.
sp.p: Here. I pray sir, save me: I'll get my Mothe● to end y●. 〈◊〉 up a couple of capons.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Because thou art a free man, and thy follies come of simple 〈◊〉 〈◊〉, and are not deepely rooted in thee, there is hope of thy recovery. For three years thou shalt pay but an hour in the week, and all thy school time 〈◊〉 depart from the presence and guidance of Philoponus. Observe and imitate his painful diligence: so shalt thou get the muse's love, and lord Apollo favour.

sp.speaker: No●.
sp.p: Thanks, many ▪ thanks to him, and thee for this your clemency.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Good your worship, be good to my son, his mother will run mad for gri●.

sp.speaker: M●s.
sp.p: Thy son ▪ come hither Retro.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Ferem doo●is.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Mercy sir, mercy.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p:
Apollo has accepted thy submission, and cu● of the third year of thy punishment. Arise, and show
thy face, thy tongue may now run right, and speak as others do. You may be a forward child.

sp.speaker: Retro.
sp.p: Thanks, oh most forward thanks, for the restoring of my distorted limbs and tongue.
Retiring Crabbe farewell. Welcome humane pace.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: But see thou holdest the scholars even path, nor striding f●st, nor wandering from the way.

sp.speaker: Geron.
sp.p: Thanks sacred priest I shall bring my wife joyful news.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Now is Apollo's garden weeded quite,
Composed in order, swept, and cleanly dight.
Now may each tender plant, and goodly flower
Grow up, and th●e, by heaven's assisting power.
Praco, dissolve the session.

sp.speaker: Praco.
sp.p: Oyez, our sovereign lord Apollo, having held and finished his visitation, dischargeth all suitors, parties, and homagers from their attendance in this place; and licenseth all his subjects and servants, to depart to their sever all habitations.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Uincat Apollo. Regnet Apollo.

sp.speaker: Clio.
sp.l: It joys my heart, that we poor muses,
Now have redress of our abuses.

sp.speaker: Euterpe.
sp.l: Before alas I mourned and wept:
But now I joy: our school is swept.,

sp.speaker: O●nes.
sp.p: Vincat Apollo, regnet Apollo.

lg.l: Accept (We pray) our hasty huddled games;
Who thus employ our parts, our pains most gladly,
In hope to please our mother town of ha●y.
And thus with this our homely shroving dish,
A merry Shrovetide to you all we w●h.
T●s' late ▪ methinks I spy some drowsy head,
Whose yawning, nodding tolls a peal to bed ▪
If any such be here, we'll take them n●pping,
And all to box their ears with loud hand-clapping.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
